page.title: Arthur W. Page Center for Integrity in Public Communication

revision.text:
The '''Arthur W. Page Center for Integrity in Public Communication''' is a research center at the [[Donald P. Bellisario College of Communications]] at the [[Pennsylvania State University]]. The center is dedicated to the study and advancement of ethics and responsibility in [[corporate communication]] and other forms of public communication.<ref>http://pagecenter.comm.psu.edu/</ref>
==History== The center is named for [[Arthur W. Page]], widely regarded as the founder of modern corporate [[public relations]], whose views have been distilled into the Page Principles: (1) tell the truth; (2) prove it with action; (3) listen to stakeholders; (4) manage for tomorrow; (5) conduct public relations as if the whole enterprise depends on it; (6) realize that an enterprise's true character is expressed by its people; and (7) remain calm, patient and good-humored.<ref>http://bellisario.psu.edu/page-center/about/arthur-w-page/the-page-principles</ref>
Bringing the center to Penn State was the idea of alumnus Lawrence G. Foster, who retired as corporate vice-president of public relations at [[Johnson & Johnson]]. The launch was made possible by a $300,000 gift he and his wife Ellen made to the college. Foster worked on the project with Edward M. Block, retired vice-president of public relations at [[AT&T]], and John A. Koten, retired senior vice president of corporate communications at [[Ameritech]]. All three played leading roles in the formation of [http://www.awpagesociety.com The Arthur W. Page Society], which functions as a separate entity.
==The Arthur W. Page Center Awards== The Page Center annually honors individuals who, over the course of their careers, have demonstrated consistent and fervent commitment to the concept of “truth well told." Three icons of the profession are recognized each February at an awards dinner held in New York City. Hundreds of professionals attend as the honorees are given a Larry Foster Award for Integrity in Public Communication, named after the center's founder. Past honorees include Ann Barkelew, Dick Martin, Alan Murray,<ref>http://bellisario.psu.edu/page-center/events/archive-awards2017</ref> [[Bill George (academic)|Bill George]], [[Gwen Ifill]] and John Onoda.<ref>http://bellisario.psu.edu/page-center/events/archive-awards2018</ref>
==Research and projects==
The Page Center seeks to foster a modern understanding and application of the Page principles and Robert Wood Johnson’s business philosophy by supporting innovative research, educational or public service projects in a variety of academic disciplines and professional fields.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pagecenter.comm.psu.edu/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D276 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-07-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720032301/http://pagecenter.comm.psu.edu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=276 |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }}</ref>
The center supports three ongoing programs, as set out below.
===Page/Johnson legacy scholars=== As of April 2018, the center has awarded more than $900,000 to scholars and professionals throughout the world to support research that makes important contributions to knowledge, practice or public understanding of ethics and responsibility in public communication or other principles of Arthur W. Page. Topics of research have included digital media, corporate social responsibility, sustainability, advocacy and fake news. <ref>http://bellisario.psu.edu/page-center/grants/legacy-scholar-grants</ref>
===Oral history collection=== Printable transcripts, streaming video, and searchable indexed content provide history, analysis and individual comment on public relations and the media from the luminaries in the field. To date, the Center has conducted 31 interviews and has transcribed and indexed many acquired videos from the Arthur W. Page Society and other contributors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pagecenter.comm.psu.edu/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D276 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-07-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720032301/http://pagecenter.comm.psu.edu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=276 |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }}</ref>
===Page archive=== The Page Center also is the archive for Page’s previously uncollected papers and memorabilia and related research materials in the area of ethics in public communication and corporate responsibility.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Business ethics organizations]]

revision.text:
'''Bankruptcy prediction''' is the art of predicting [[bankruptcy]] and various measures of [[financial distress]] of public firms. It is a vast area of finance and accounting research. The importance of the area is due in part to the relevance for [[creditor]]s and [[investor]]s in evaluating the likelihood that a firm may go bankrupt.
The quantity of research is also a function of the availability of data: for public firms which went bankrupt or did not, numerous accounting ratios that might indicate danger can be calculated, and numerous other potential explanatory variables are also available. Consequently, the area is well-suited for testing of increasingly sophisticated, data-intensive [[forecasting]] approaches.
==History== The history of bankruptcy prediction includes application of numerous statistical tools which gradually became available, and involves deepening appreciation of various pitfalls in early analyses. Research is still published that suffers pitfalls that have been understood for many years.
Bankruptcy prediction has been a subject of formal analysis since at least 1932, when FitzPatrick published a study of 20 pairs of firms, one failed and one surviving, matched by date, size and industry, in ''The Certified Public Accountant''. He did not perform statistical analysis as is now common, but he thoughtfully interpreted the ratios and trends in the ratios. His interpretation was effectively a complex, multiple variable analysis.
In 1967, [[William Beaver]] applied [[t-tests]] to evaluate the importance of individual accounting ratios within a similar pair-matched sample.
In 1968, in the first formal multiple variable analysis, [[Edward I. Altman]] applied [[multiple discriminant analysis]] within a pair-matched sample. One of the most prominent early models of bankruptcy prediction is the [[Altman Z-score]], which is still applied today.
In 1980, [[James Ohlson]] applied [[logit regression]] in a much larger sample that did not involve pair-matching.
==Modern methods== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2014}} Survival methods are now applied.
Option valuation approaches involving stock price variability have been developed. Under structural models,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fields.utoronto.ca/programs/scientific/09-10/finance/courses/hurdnotes2.pdf|title=Structural Modes of Credit Risk|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> a default event is deemed to occur for a firm when its assets reach a sufficiently low level compared to its liabilities.
[[Neural network model]]s and other sophisticated models have been tested on bankruptcy prediction.
Modern methods applied by business information companies surpass the annual accounts content and also consider current events like age, judgements, bad press, payment incidents and payment experiences from creditors.
==Comparison of differing approaches ==
The latest research within the field of Bankruptcy and Insolvency Prediction compares various differing approaches, modelling techniques, and individual models to ascertain whether any one technique is superior to its counterparts.
Jackson and Wood (2013) provides an excellent discussion of the literature to date, including an empirical evaluation of 15 popular models from the existing literature. These models range from the univariate models of Beaver through the multidimensional models of Altman and Ohlson, and continuing to more recent techniques which include option valuation approaches. They find that models based on market data - such as an option valuation approach - outperform those earlier models which rely heavily on accounting numbers.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0890838913000498 | doi=10.1016/j.bar.2013.06.009 | volume=45 | title=The performance of insolvency prediction and credit risk models in the UK: A comparative study | journal=The British Accounting Review | pages=183–202}}</ref>
Zhang, Wang, and Ji (2013) proposed a novel [[rule-based system]] to solve bankruptcy prediction problem. The whole procedure consists of the following four stages: first, sequential [[forward selection]] was used to extract the most important features; second, a rule-based model was chosen to fit the given dataset since it can present physical meaning; third, a genetic [[ant colony algorithm]] (GACA) was introduced; the fitness scaling strategy and the chaotic operator were incorporated with GACA, forming a new algorithm—fitness-scaling chaotic GACA (FSCGACA), which was used to seek the optimal parameters of the rule-based model; and finally, the [[Cross-validation_(statistics)#k-fold_cross-validation|stratified K-fold cross-validation]] technique was used to enhance the generalization of the model.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zhang|first=Yudong|author2=Shuihua Wang |author3=Genlin Ji |title=A Rule-Based Model for Bankruptcy Prediction Based on an Improved Genetic Ant Colony Algorithm|journal=Mathematical Problems in Engineering|date=2013|volume=2013|doi=10.1155/2013/753251|url=http://downloads.hindawi.com/journals/mpe/2013/753251.pdf|page=753251}}</ref>
==References== {{More footnotes|date=February 2014}} {{reflist}} *[[FitzPatrick 1932]] *Beaver 1966. Financial ratios predictors of failure. ''[[Journal of Accounting Research]], 4 (Supplement), p. 71-111. *Beaver 1968 *{{cite journal | last1 = Altman | first1 = Edward I | year = 1968 | title = Financial ratios, discriminant analysis and the prediction of corporate bankruptcy | url = | journal = [[Journal of Finance]] | volume = 23 | issue = 4| pages = 589–609 }} *Ohlson, James. 1980. *{{cite journal | last1 = Balcaen | first1 = Sofie | last2 = Ooghe | first2 = Hubert | year = 2006 | title = 35 years of studies on business failure: an overview of the classic statistical methodologies and their related problems | url = | journal = [[British Accounting Review]] | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 63–93 }} *Zmijewski, Mark E. 1984. "Methodological issues related to the estimation of financial distress prediction models". ''[[Journal of Accounting Research]]'' 22 (Supplement), p. 59-86. *{{cite journal | last1 = Jackson | first1 = Richard | last2 = Wood | first2 = Anthony | year = 2013 | title = The Performance of Insolvency Prediction and Credit Risk Models in the UK: A Comparative Study | url = | journal = The British Accounting Review | volume = 45 | issue = 3| pages = 183–202 }} * {{cite journal | last=Danilov | first=Konstantin | title=Corporate Bankruptcy: Assessment, Analysis and Prediction of Financial Distress, Insolvency, and Failure | journal=SSRN Electronic Journal |url=http://www.ssrn.com/abstract=2467580| publisher=Elsevier BV | year=2014 | issn=1556-5068 | doi=10.2139/ssrn.2467580 | ref=harv}}
==External links==

{{Infobox company |name = BECI - Brussels Enterprises Commerce & Industry |logo = Brussels Enterprises Commerce and Industry logo.gif |foundation = 2007 |location = Louise Avenue 500, [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] |key_people = Marc Decorette <small>([[Chairman]])</small>, Olivier Willocx <small>([[chief executive officer|CEO]])</small>, Joëlle Evenepoel <small>([[Secretary General]])</small> |homepage = [http://www.beci.be www.beci.be] }}
The '''Brussels Enterprises Commerce and Industry''' (BECI) organization is a [[non profit]] organization representing companies of the [[Brussels-Capital Region]] of [[Belgium]]. Its members, the different Brussels enterprises, represent companies in key industrial and service sectors. President of BECI is [[Marc Decorte]] and CEO is [[:fr:Olivier Willocx]].
==See also== * [[Federation of Belgian Enterprises]] * [[VOKA]] * [[Walloon Union of Companies]] * [[Science and technology in the Brussels-Capital Region]] * [[Brussels Regional Investment Company]]
==Sources== * [http://www.beci.be/ Brussels Enterprises Commerce and Industry] (French) * [http://www.beci.be/ BECI] (French)
==External links== * [http://www.beci.be/ BECI]

{{EngvarB|date=May 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Chinese name|[[Cao (surname)|Cao (Chao)]]}} '''Chao Kuang-piu, [[Silver Bauhinia Star|SBS]]''' ({{zh|c=曹光彪|p=Cáo Guāngbiāo|cy=Chou<sup>4</sup> Gwong<sup>1</sup> Biu<sup>1</sup>}} born 24 November 1920), is a Hong Kong [[Business magnate|industrial tycoon]] and philanthropist, sometimes referred to as Hong Kong's "Wool Magnate". {{citation needed|date=November 2009}}
==Life== Chao was born on 24 November 1920 in [[Shanghai]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whartonhongkong07.com/bio-s-chao.html|title=Biography of K.P. Chao : The Wharton Global Alumni Forum-Hong Kong|author=|date=|website=www.whartonhongkong07.com|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref> His father was also a successful businessman in Shanghai. In 1950, Chao went to Hong Kong to develop his own business. His career has been mainly involved in the Hong Kong textile industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baf.cuhk.edu.hk/research/gem/_new/en/research/hke_abstract.asp?hke_id=19|title=Hong Kong Entrepreneur Series|author=|date=|website=cuhk.edu.hk|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
Chao was the main founder of the [[Dragonair]], which was the first Chinese air company in Hong Kong. Chao also was the very first businessman who invested in [[Mainland China]] when the [[Chinese Economic Reform]] started in late 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/292416.htm|title=曹光彪_百度百科|author=|date=|website=baidu.com|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
Chao is the current Honorary Chairman of the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School's Global Alumni Forum]] in Hong Kong. He is also the current Chairman of Novel Enterprises Ltd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whartonhongkong07.com/00-h-chairman.html|title=Welcome from the Honorary Chairman : The Wharton Global Alumni Forum-Hong Kong|author=|date=|website=www.whartonhongkong07.com|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
==Family== Chao's daughter, [[Susana Chou|Susana K J Chou]] (曹其真, b. 1941), is the first President of the [[Legislative Assembly of Macau]], [[Macau Special Administrative Region|Macau SAR]].
Chao's son, [[Silas Chou|Silas K F Chou]] (曹其峰), is a director of Novel Enterprises which owned Tommy Hilfiger and Michael Kors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whartonhongkong07.com/bio-s-chou.html|title=Biography of Silas K. F. Chou|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> His daughter is socialite Veronica Chou (曹颖惠, b. 1984).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://next.ft.com/content/4a6483ea-b66f-11e3-b230-00144feabdc0|title=Heiress Veronica Chou on her Beijing ‘courtyard house in the sky’|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Chao's son, Ronald K Y Chao (曹其镛, b. 1939), is also a director of Novel Enterprises and founded the Bai Xian Scholarship program in Hong Kong.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bxai.org/en-us/who-we-are/about-us/honorary-chairman|title=Honorary Chairman - Bai Xian Asia Institute|website=www.bxai.org|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1362498/businessman|title=Businessman|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Chao studied Mechanical Engineering at University of Tokyo and obtained MS at the University of Illinois.
==Honours and awards== * The [[4566 Chaokuangpiu|Asteroid 4566 Chao Kuang Piu]] is named after him * [[Silver Bauhinia Star]] * Wharton School Dean's Medal, awarded by the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Portal|Hong Kong|Biography}} * [http://www.whartonhongkong07.com/bio-s-chao.html Biography of Kuang-Piu (K.P.) Chao] * [http://www.whartonhongkong07.com/00-h-chairman.html Welcome from the Honorary Chairman]

revision.text:
{{other people|Charles Biddle}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Charles Biddle | image = File:Charles Biddle. Vice Pres't of the Supreme Exece. Counl. of Pennsylvania - DMS (monogram). LCCN2016649133.jpg | order = 7th | office = Vice-President of Pennsylvania | president = [[John Dickinson]]
[[Benjamin Franklin]] | term_start = 10 October 1785 | term_end = 31 October 1787 | predecessor = [[James Irvine (Pennsylvania statesman)|James Irvine]] | successor = [[Peter Muhlenberg]] | birth_date = December 24, 1745 | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], [[Province of Pennsylvania]], [[British America]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1821|04|04|1745|12|24}} | death_place = Philadelphia, [[Pennsylvania]], U.S. | party = | residence = | parents = William Biddle III
Mary Scull Biddle | spouse = {{marriage|Hannah Shepard
|November 25, 1778|1821|reason=his death}} | children = 10, including [[James Biddle (commodore)|James]], [[Nicholas Biddle (banker)|Nicholas]], [[Thomas Biddle|Thomas]], [[John Biddle (Michigan politician)|John]], [[Richard Biddle|Richard]] | relations = ''See'' [[Biddle family]] | profession = | religion = }} '''Charles Biddle''' (December 24, 1745 – April 4, 1821) was a [[Pennsylvania]] statesman and a member of the prominent [[Biddle family]] of [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. ==Early life== Biddle was born to a wealthy old [[Quaker]] family on December 24, 1745 in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] in what was then the British [[Province of Pennsylvania]]. He was the son of William Biddle, 3rd (1698–1756) and Mary ([[née]] Scull) Biddle (1709–1789). His siblings included: Lydia Biddle, who married William Macfunn; John "Jacky" Biddle, who married Sophia Boone; [[Edward Biddle]], a lawyer, soldier, delegate to the [[Continental Congress]],{{Cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B000440/|title=BIDDLE, Edward - Biographical Information|publisher=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|website=bioguide.congress.gov|access-date=2016-04-09}} who married Elizabeth Ross, sister of [[George Ross (delegate)|George Ross]]; Charles Biddle, and [[Nicholas Biddle (naval officer)|Nicholas Biddle]], Revolutionary War Navy captain.{{cite book |last1=Biddle |first1=Charles |last2=Biddle |first2=James S. |title=Autobiography of Charles Biddle, vice-president of the Supreme Executive Council of Pennsylvania. 1745-1821 |date=1883 |publisher=E. Claxton and Company |location=[[Philadelphia, PA]] |url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924028831259 |accessdate=4 June 2018}} As a youth, Biddle was a schoolmate and close friend of [[Mathias Aspden]] and [[Founding Father of the United States|Founding Father]] [[Benjamin Rush]].{{cite book |last1=Rush |first1=Benjamin |title=Benjamin Rush's Lectures on the Mind |date=1981 |publisher=[[American Philosophical Society]] |isbn=9780871691446 |page=129 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sfpu7mMW9qIC&pg=PA129 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} ==Career== During the [[American Revolutionary War]], Biddle was a captain in the merchant service and participated in the work around of the British fleet's blockade of American ports. He volunteered in the Quaker Light Infantry and, in 1778, he served under his brother, Commodore [[Nicholas Biddle (naval officer)|Nicholas Biddle]], aboard the [[USS Randolph (1776)|USS ''Randolph'']]. ===Political career=== Biddle served as [[Supreme Executive Council of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania|Vice-President of Pennsylvania]] from October 10, 1785 until October 31, 1787 (also known as the [[Lieutenant Governor of Pennsylvania]]).{{cite web |title=Charles Biddle (1745-1821) |url=https://www.archives.upenn.edu/people/1700s/biddle_charles.html |website=www.archives.upenn.edu |publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania|University of Pennsylvania University Archives]] |accessdate=4 June 2018}} He served under [[John Dickinson]] and [[Benjamin Franklin]] and hosted [[George Washington]].{{cite book |last1=Stewart |first1=David O. |title=The Summer of 1787: The Men Who Invented the Constitution |date=2007 |publisher=[[Simon and Schuster]] |isbn=9781416554042 |page=231 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NveNQBMwpLEC&pg=PA231 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} During his term, he was an ''ex officio'' trustee of the University of the State of Pennsylvania (now the [[University of Pennsylvania]]). He was a member of the [[Pennsylvania Senate]] from 1810 to 1814.{{cite web | last = Cox | first = Harold | title = Senate Members C | publisher = Wilkes University | work = [[Wilkes University Election Statistics Project]]| date = | url =http://staffweb.wilkes.edu/harold.cox/legis/SC.html}} He also was an associate of [[Aaron Burr]], having introduced Burr to his wife [[Theodosia Bartow Prevost|Theodosia]] shortly after the death of her first husband, [[Jacques Marcus Prevost]].{{cite book |last1=Abraham |first1=David |title=Aaron Burr - Adventurer |date=2013 |publisher=AuthorHouse |isbn=9781481713146 |page=7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q6f1PiiP_6EC&pg=PA7 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} Although Biddle vacated his seat at Council on October 13, 1787 the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania records that his Vice-Presidential term extended to October 31, the date of the next Presidential and Vice-Presidential elections. Biddle was elected Secretary of the Council on October 23. ==Personal life== [[File:Thomas Sully - Portrait of Major John Biddle.jpg||right|thumb|Portrait of Biddle's son, [[John Biddle (Michigan politician)|John Biddle]], by [[Thomas Sully]], 1818]] {{See also|Biddle family}} On November 24, 1778, he was married to Hannah Shepard (d. 1825), the daughter of merchant Jacob Shepard and Sara (née Lewis) Shepard, in [[Beaufort, North Carolina]].{{cite book |last1=Powell |first1=William S. |title=Dictionary of North Carolina Biography: Vol. 5, P-S |date=2000 |publisher=[[Univ of North Carolina Press]] |isbn=9780807867006 |page=328 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VeSDB5tKDagC&pg=PA328 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} The Biddle family had a summer home outside of Philadelphia that was furnished sumptuously with English furniture and paintings. Together, they were the parents of ten children, including:{{cite book |last1=Jordan |first1=John W. |title=Colonial And Revolutionary Families Of Pennsylvania |date=2004 |publisher=Genealogical Publishing Com |isbn=9780806352398 |pages=167-168 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arAfWBsvO1gC&pg=PA167 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}}{{cite book |last1=Davis |first1=William Watts Hart |title=A Genealogical and Personal History of Bucks County, Pennsylvania |date=1975 |publisher=Genealogical Publishing Com |isbn=9780806306414 |page=159 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-nEHRwRAwxAC&pg=PA159 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} * Mary Biddle (d. 1854), who married John Gideon Biddle (1793–1826), the fourth son of Clement Biddle, in 1820.{{cite book |last1=Glenn |first1=Thomas Allen |title=Merion in the Welsh Tract: With Sketches of the Townships of Haverford and Radnor. Historical and Genealogical Collections Concerning the Welsh Barony in the Province of Pennsylvania, Settled by the Cymric Quakers in 1682 |date=1970 |publisher=Genealogical Publishing Com |isbn=9780806304298 |page=145 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fmiqHA3Fe2oC&pg=PA145 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} * Nicholas Biddle (b. 1779), who died in infancy. * William Shephard Biddle (1781–1835), who married Circe Deroneray. After her death, he married Elizabeth Bordeon Hopkinson, daughter of [[Joseph Hopkinson]]. * [[James Biddle (commodore)|James Biddle]] (1783–1848), a commodore with the [[U.S. Navy]] who died unmarried. * Edward Biddle (1784–1800), a midshipman with the U.S. Navy who died at sea. * [[Nicholas Biddle (banker)|Nicholas Biddle]] (1786–1844), president of the [[Second Bank of the United States]] who married Jane Craig. * Charles Biddle Jr. (1787–1836), who married Anna H. Stokes in 1808.{{cite book |last1=[[Daughters of the American Revolution]] |title=Lineage Book - National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution |date=1904 |publisher=Daughters of the American Revolution |page=101 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p2sZAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA101 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} * [[Thomas Biddle]] (1790–1831), a [[War of 1812]] hero who died after a duel with a Missouri Congressman over a perceived insult to his brother Nicholas. He married M. Ann Mulllanphy. * [[John Biddle (Michigan politician)|John Biddle]] (1792–1859), Michigan politician who married Eliza Falconer Bradish. * [[Richard Biddle]] (1796–1847), a [[U.S. Representative]] who married Ann Anderson. Biddle died on April 4, 1821 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His widow died almost four years later on January 4, 1825.{{cite book |last1=Biddle |first1=Henry Drinker |title=Notes on the Genealogy of the Biddle Family: Together with Abstracts of Some Early Deeds |date=1895 |publisher=W.S. Fortescue & Company |page=8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uGw2AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA8 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en}} ==See also== *[[Biddle family]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080516094406/http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/1700s/people/biddle_charles.html Biography at the University of Pennsylvania] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070623231431/http://diglib.princeton.edu/ead/eadGetDoc.xq?id=%2Fead%2Fmss%2FC0081.EAD.xml Fuller Collection of Aaron Burr (1756-1836), 1771-1851 (bulk 1778-1834): Finding Aid] *[http://www.fullbooks.com/Memoirs-of-Aaron-Burr-Complete14.html ''Memoirs of Aaron Burr'', Complete by Matthew L. Davis, Part 14 out of 17] * {{Find a Grave |8696865|Charles Biddle}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before=Sebastian Levan|title=Member, [[Supreme Executive Council of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania|Supreme Executive Council of Pennsylvania]],
representing [[Berks County, Pennsylvania|Berks County]] | years= 30 October 1784 – 13 October 1787| after=James Read }} {{succession box | before= [[James Irvine (Pennsylvania statesman)|James Irvine]] |title=[[Supreme Executive Council of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania#Vice-Presidents of Council|Vice-President of Pennsylvania]] | years= 10 October 1785 – 31 October 1787 | after= [[Peter Muhlenberg]] }} {{s-end}} {{Lieutenant Governors and Vice-Presidents of Pennsylvania}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Biddle, Charles}} [[Category:Biddle family|Charles]] [[Category:1745 births]] [[Category:1821 deaths]] [[Category:Pennsylvania state senators]] [[Category:American people of English descent]]

revision.text:
{{See also|Consignment}} {{Unreferenced|date=April 2009}} {{Admiralty law}} In a [[contract of carriage]], the '''consignee''' is the entity who is financially responsible (the buyer) for the receipt of a [[shipment]]. Generally, but not always, the consignee is the same as the receiver.
If a sender dispatches an item to a receiver via a delivery service, the sender is the ''sender'', the recipient is the ''consignee'', and the deliverer is the ''carrier''.
==A brief statement of law== This is a difficult area of [[law]] in that it regulates the mass [[transport]]ation industry which cannot always guarantee arrival on time or that [[good (accounting)|goods]] will not be damaged in the course of transit. Furthermore, two other problems are that unpaid consignors or [[freight]] carriers may wish to hold goods until payment is made, and [[fraudulent]] individuals may seek to take delivery in place of the [[Legitimacy (criminal law)|legitimate]] consignees. The key to resolving such disputes lies in the [[documentation]]. The standard form of contract is a [[bill of lading]] which, in international shipping law, is simply a contract for the carriage of goods entered into between the shipper and the carrier that is not a [[Charter-party|charter party]]. It is always a term of that contract that the carrier must deliver the goods to a specific receiver.
=== Documentation and legal requirements for delivery ===
A straight bill of lading by land or sea, or air [[waybill]] are not documents of title to the goods they represent. They do no more than require delivery of the goods to the named consignee and (subject to the shipper's ability to redirect the goods) to no other. This differs from an "order" or "bearer" bill of lading which are possessory title documents and negotiable, i.e. they can be endorsed and so transfer the right to take delivery to the last endorsee. This aspect of shipping law is regulated by the [[Hague Rules]], and the laws of individual countries, e.g. the UK Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1992 and the U.S. Pomerene Act 1916. There is some international dispute as to whether the consignee on a straight bill must produce the bill in order to take delivery. The U.S. position is that the person taking delivery must prove his or her identity but, as in [[Hong Kong]], there is no need to present the bill itself. In the UK there are conflicting ''[[obiter dicta]]'' in "The Rafaela S" [2003] 2 Lloyd's Rep. 113 and "The Happy Ranger" [2002] 2 AER (Comm) 23, so the matter must remain unclear even though there are serious problems, for example, arising from the everyday occurrence of [[cargo]] being discharged against letters of indemnity when original bills of lading are not yet available to be presented at the discharge [[port]].
=== Consignee rights ===
The rights of the consignee under an air waybill are regulated by the [[Warsaw Convention]] for the Unification of Certain Rules for International Carriage by Air, 1929 and the [[Montreal Convention]] for the Unification of Certain Rules for International Carriage by Air 1999 and the relevant state laws (which may be one law chosen as the proper law by the parties, or any combination of laws representing the seller, buyer, consignor, and carrier.) This is very important as per export documents.
The receiver can be different than that of the consignee.
[[Category:Freight transport]] [[Category:Legal documents]] [[Category:Contract law]] [[Category:Transport law]] ===IMPORTANCE=== It is helpful to give and take the information about to be paid and received. It helps to settle dispute as it includes the detail about the goods and terms of [[trade]] and payment. It informs the selling price to the [[consignee]]. It helps to know the quality , the quantity, the price and the discount to the importer.

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''Downtown Athens''' is the oldest of the main commercial and residential centers in [[Athens, Georgia|Athens]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]]. Downtown is generally considered to be the area bounded by Dougherty Street on the north, Broad Street and the [[University of Georgia]] campus on the south, Pulaski Street on the west, and Foundry Street by the east.
A [[Downtown Athens Historic District]] was listed on the National Register of Historic Places by Austin Kinsey in 1978.
The commercial and governmental heart of the city has traditionally been toward the eastern end of Downtown Athens, between Lumpkin and Thomas Streets. Recent developments, particularly between Lumpkin and Pulaski Streets, have expanded the boundaries of the "central" part of the neighborhood. The term "Downtown Athens" can also mean this smaller, more commercial area, particularly when used in the context of the city's nightlife and restaurants.
Some definitions of "Downtown" include the area west of Pulaski Street, which is a much more residential area characterized by historic homes, new infill construction, and some public housing. This part of Downtown Athens has the highest concentration of hotels {{citation needed|date=October 2010}} particularly along Broad Street. The Prince Avenue commercial corridor is an important center of business, particularly for those living in the [[Boulevard (Athens)|Boulevard]] and [[Normaltown (Athens)|Normaltown]] neighborhoods.
The area has several hotels and apartment buildings, and more high-rise condos are either under construction or planned for the area. Some of these high-rises as well as the construction of the new Multi-Modal Transportation Center have the potential to redefine the area encompassing downtown Athens to stretch east to the banks of the [[Oconee River]].
[[Image:Dt athens.jpg|600px|thumb|center|A map of Athens with Downtown and UGA shaded. Note that the common definition of Downtown does not include the area west of Pulaski Street.]]
== Defining "Downtown Athens" ==
The exact delineation of what is "Downtown" differs for varying purposes. Some of the more common ones are:
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! South !! North !! East !! West !! Function/context, etc. |- | Broad St || Hancock St || Foundry St || Pulaski St || This is the boundary of the "no-cruising zone" established by Athens-Clarke County ordinance. ("No cruising" means no motor vehicle may pass the same point within the zone more than three times in an hour, during the hours of midnight to 4 a.m.) [http://library.municode.com/HTML/12400/level3/PIII_T3_C3-3.html#PIII_T3_C3-3_s3-3-64] |- | Broad St || Dougherty St || Foundry St || Pulaski St || This is the common definition of Downtown, clearly distinguished from the rest of Athens by such things as building density, metered on-street parking, etc. Athens-Clarke County uses a distinctive street sign design (using the ACC logo on signs) within this boundary. |- | Broad St || Dougherty St/ Prince Ave || Foundry St || Milledge Ave || This is a more generous area of Downtown, including the above in addition to the Broad Street and Prince Avenue corridors immediately to the west of the core of Downtown. |}
== Cultural significance ==
The Downtown area is the cultural center of the city. Several dozen night clubs host performances of local, regional and national bands and artists. The [[40 Watt Club]] at the corner of Washington and Pulaski and [[Georgia Theater]] on Lumpkin Street between Clayton and Washington are among the most well-known night spots where many bands have made the jump to a larger regional stage (See [[Music of Athens, Georgia]]). The Classic Center, located on Thomas Street on the eastern edge of the neighborhood, is a multi-purpose facility containing a performing arts center, convention space, and banquet halls. It was a filming site for ''[[Blue Collar TV]]''.
== Restaurants and bars ==
Downtown Athens is home to award-winning restaurants<ref>http://www.visitathensga.com/restaurants/award-winning-dining/</ref> including The Last Resort and Weaver D's. Five & Ten, a high class expensive restaurant is known for the famous chef, [[Hugh Acheson]], who was named Best Chef Southeast by the James Beard Foundation<ref>http://www.visitathensga.com/restaurants/award-winning-dining/</ref> and also on [[Top Chef: Masters (season 3)]]. Other notable restaurants include The Porterhouse Grill and De Palmas. There are a variety of eating options, ranging from higher-priced luxury dining, chain restaurants, ethnic food restaurants, and inexpensive bar food.<ref>http://voices.yahoo.com/you-havent-tasted-pizza-athens-georgia-6872758.html?cat=22{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The streets, particularly on Thursday through Saturday, are filled with people and cars late into the night. Popular bars are on every street corner, including Magnolia's, Allgood, Blue Sky, Silver Dollar, General Beauregard's, Walker's Pub, Boars Head, Sandbar and Trappeze. There are around 80 bars in Athens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownathensga.com/businesses.php?category%3D29 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812061825/http://www.downtownathensga.com/businesses.php?category=29 |archivedate=2014-08-12 |df= }}</ref> In recent years, nightlife for this demographic has been concentrated in the neighborhood's rapidly changing "West End", the area between Lumpkin and Pulaski Streets. Nightlife catering to a more mainstream college-age demographic remains in the eastern part of the neighborhood, especially along Broad and Clayton Streets. During the day, visitors of all ages can find a reason to visit Downtown Athens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/the-pros-cons-downtown-athens-georgia-11203126.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728235949/http://voices.yahoo.com/the-pros-cons-downtown-athens-georgia-11203126.html |archivedate=2014-07-28 |df= }}</ref>
== Shopping == Locally- owned fashion boutiques line the streets, including Encore, Heery's and Cheeky Peach that all include designer brand names. Catering to the city's diverse populations, vintage shops like Agora and Cillies host a variety of items. Many of these outlets reflect Athens's status as a university town and a small liberal city. In particular, independent music stores such as the world-famous Wuxtry Records and alternative shops are found along Clayton Street, as well as the Georgia Bulldogs fan shop known as The Red Zone.
== Government ==
The Athens-Clarke County unified government is located in the Downtown district. Several local and federal government buildings are located along Washington Street, and the county adult health center is located just within the western boundary of Downtown.
==References==

{{Infobox person |name = Ely Calil |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1945|12|8|df=y}} |birth_place = Kano |death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|5|28|1945|12|8|df=yes}} |death_place = London |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }}
'''Ely Calil''' (8 December 1945 – 28 May 2018) was a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] businessman holding [[United Kingdom|British]] citizenship. He was one of the richest men in Britain; ''[[The Sunday Times Magazine]]'' estimated his wealth in 2010 to be around £350 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/|title=The Times & The Sunday Times|language=en|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>
==Life== His ancestry can be traced back to 1920s or 30s when his family set up their home in what's today [[Turkey]] after leaving [[Lebanon]], but then returned to Lebanon after [[Ataturk]]'s policies discriminating against [[Christianity in Turkey|Christians]]. Before he was born, his family set up an oil mill for groundnut processing in Lebanon in 1941. His father, George Khalil, died in 1970, leaving behind two sons, him [Ely] and Bernard, and was said to have bequeathed £20 million to Ely.<ref>{{cite web|title=Under fire: Lebanese millionaire who seems to know everybody|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/under-fire-lebanese-millionaire-who-seems-to-know-everybody-53489.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=26 August 2004}}</ref>
==Allegations == In 2002, Calil was arrested in [[Paris]] in connection with the [[Elf Aquitaine]] scandal but was released on appeal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/|title=The Times & The Sunday Times|language=en|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>
In 2004 Calil was alleged to be part in the failed [[2004 Equatorial Guinea coup d'état attempt|coup d'état in Equatorial Guinea]] and is currently sought by courts both in Equatorial Guinea and [[South Africa]].<ref>Blaisse, Mark. ''Rich, Betrayed en Lonely. Reconstruction of the international plot against Equatorial Guinea'' (PREG Publications, Malabo, 2011){{pageneeded|date=December 2015}}</ref> In September 2004, he was sued by the Equatorial Guinean government for allegedly having raised $750 000 to finance the plot.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK businessman sued for coup|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/UK-businessman-sued-for-coup-20040910|publisher=News 24 Archives|accessdate=10 September 2004}}</ref>
==Personal life== He married his first wife, a [[Tennessee]] tobacco heiress named Frances Condon, at [[Roman Catholic]] church in Farm Street, [[Mayfair]] in 1972. The couple divorced in 1985, and the following year, Calil married a Lebanese socialite, Hayat Emma Morowa. The marriage also failed, and Calil married his third wife, Renuka Jaine, in 1989. He died on 28 May 2018 after falling down stairs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/ely-calil-oil-wonga-coup-equatorial-guinea-simon-mann-mark-thatcher-a8382886.html|title=Ely Calil: The oil magnate who financed the failed 'wonga coup' in Equatorial Guinea|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.crimelibrary.com/gangsters_outlaws/cops_others/thatcher_and_mann/13.html Mark Thatcher & Simon Mann's African coup - The Crime library]

'''Fana Hlongwane''' is a South African politician and businessman. He is chiefly known for his association with the [[South African Arms Deal]], when he was adviser to defence minister [[Joe Modise]] from 1995 to 1998.<ref>[http://www.citypress.co.za/SouthAfrica/News/Weapons-built-luxury-house-20110702 Weapons built luxury house] ''City Press''</ref><ref name=defenceweb>[http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?view=article&id=17461 Fana Hlongwane] ''Defence Web''</ref>
His various companies, Ngwane Defence, Truvelo, Les Amis (Pty) Ltd, Hlongwane Consulting channelled around 200 million Rand from [[British Aerospace]] which are alleged to be bribes distributed around the ANC. Swedish authorities say that R24 million was paid to Hlongwane in 2003.<ref name=defenceweb/> Former British Aerospace project manager [[Bernard Collier]] paid R7 million in April 2007 to Hlongwane as a consultant via the company Ivema, itself 51% owned by Hlongwane through Ngwane Defence Holdings.<ref name=defenceweb/><ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2010-03-21-court-papers-allege-payments-to-hlongwane Court papers allege 'payments to Hlongwane'] ''M&G''</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Orphan|date=February 2013}}
'''FUCAFF''' ([http://www.fucaff.com Website]) is the [[acronym]] for the '''Federation of Uganda Customs Agents & Freight Forwarders''', an exclusive umbrella association for member clearing firms or companies registered in [[Uganda]]. With the [[slogan]] ''Fostering Tax Compliance with Stakeholders'', it was formed in 2009 after [[UCIFA]] and its offshoot [[UFFA (Uganda)|UFFA]] to coordinate with [[Uganda Revenue Authority|URA]].
==Logistics==
The [[federation]]'s secretariat is based in Kinawataka, [[Kampala]] behind the Railway Crossing and fosters [[clearing (finance)|clearing]] and [[freight forwarding]] management within the [[Northern Corridor]] - the Busiest Transport Network in East Africa. With [[integrity]] as a vital component in leadership, it is mandatory for member companies of FUCAFF to be registered with [[Uganda Revenue Authority]].
==See also==
* [[Transport in Uganda]] * [[Northern Corridor]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Federation of Uganda Customs Agents and Freight Forwarders}} [[Category:Business organisations based in Uganda]] [[Category:Freight forwarders associations]]

{{Infobox company | name = Fiduciary Institute of Southern Africa (FISA) | foundation = {{start date|2008}} | type = Non-profit professional association | key_people = Eben Nel (Chairperson); Louis van Vuren (CEO) | members = 700+ | homepage = [http://www.fidsa.org.za/ www.fidsa.org.za] | image = File:Fiduciary_Institute_of_South_Africa_logo_2013.jpg }}
The '''Fiduciary Institute of Southern Africa''' (FISA) is a non-profit professional organisation. It represents [[fiduciary]] practitioners and sets high minimum standards for the industry .<ref>Personal Finance databank</ref><ref>You magazine, 16 January 2014</ref>
==Formation and activities== FISA was formed in 2008, when the Association of Trust Companies in South Africa (ATCSA), which was formed in 1932, was converted to a professional institute with individual membership. A new constitution was adopted to reflect the change of name and membership. Prior to the change, members were the main [[trust companies]] in South Africa on a corporate membership basis. After the change, members include employees of trust companies and individuals from the legal, accounting and financial planning professions.
FISA has approximately 700 individual members, who collectively manage assets in excess of R250 billion. They draft tens of thousand [[Wills]] each year and administer around 50 percent of deceased estates reported to the offices of the [http://www.justice.gov.za/master/m_main.htm Master of the High Court] in [[South Africa]].
Activities of FISA members include [[estate planning]], the drafting of Wills], administration of trusts and estates, [[beneficiary fund]]s, tax and financial advice and the management of client funds.
The organization is governed by a 10-person Council; the current Chairperson is Eben Nel. Regional councilors represent the regions of [[Gauteng]], [[Western Cape]], [[Eastern Cape]], [[KwaZulu Natal]], and [[Free State (province)|Free State]]. The intention is to add other regional representation as membership grows. There are also seven special purpose committees comprising experts in the areas of trusts, estates, compliance, tax, education and training, and beneficiary funds.
FISA liaises with the Master's Office and the [[South African Revenue Service]] in order to participate in optimising legal and compliance processes. It engages with the [[National Treasury (South Africa)|South African Treasury]] on issues that affect the industry and the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.golegal.co.za/business/future-taxation-trusts |title=The future taxation of trusts |publisher=Go Legal |date= |accessdate=2014-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222100440/http://www.golegal.co.za/business/future-taxation-trusts |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>Mercury, 26 June 2013</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.iol.co.za/business/personal-finance/tax/plan-to-tax-capital-gains-as-income-will-kill-discretionary-trusts-1.1479432#.UvNDUPZ4J34 |title=Plan to tax capital gains as income will kill discretionary trusts - Personal Finance Tax | IOL Business |publisher=IOL.co.za |date=2013-03-03 |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref>
==Education== FISA aims to raise awareness and standards of fiduciary practice through education to benefit both practitioners and the public. FISA holds an annual conference at which practitioners and academics in the fiduciary field present and discuss topical issues.<ref>De Rebus, 1 November 2013</ref><ref>InvestSA, 1 November 2013</ref> In 2011 FISA introduced a professional examination, in co-operation with the [[University of the Free State]], which gives successful candidates the designation of Fiduciary Practitioner of South Africa (FPSA®).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investsa.co.za/fisa-ramps-up-fiduciary-profession-2/ |title=FISA ramps up fiduciary profession |publisher=Investsa |date= |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.moneymarketing.co.za/fiduciary-profession-sa/ |title=Fiduciary profession in SA |publisher=Money-Marketing |date=2013-08-28 |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref>
==Outreach== FISA works actively to educate the public about fiduciary issues. It has a public helpdesk on its website which contains a complaints procedure<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fidsa.org.za/complaints/ |title=Complaints - FISA |publisher=Fidsa.org.za |date= |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref> and consumer education on executorships, Wills, and trusts<. For the benefit of both its members and the public, the institute makes available the latest court decisions on fiduciary matters.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://fidsa.org.za/court-case-proprietary-rights-foreign-marriage/ |title=Court case: Proprietary rights of a foreign marriage - FISA |publisher=Fidsa.org.za |date=2013-12-04 |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref>
The organization also has an active media campaign through which it educates journalists on fiduciary matters and representatives talk about fiduciary issues on radio and television.
==Affiliations== FISA has strategic alliances with other professional bodies such as the [[South African Institute of Tax Practitioners]], the Law Society of South Africa and the [[Financial Planning Institute]] with which it signed a memorandum of understanding in 2012.<ref>The Financial Planner, 1 August 2013</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.fidsa.org.za}}
[[Category:Non-profit organisations based in South Africa]] [[Category:Business and finance professional associations]] [[Category:2008 establishments in South Africa]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2008]]

{{for|the founder of the [[Ahmadiyya]] movement in Islam|Mirza Ghulam Ahmad}} {{Use Pakistani English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{refimprove|date=February 2014}} {{ Infobox scientist | name =Ghulam Ahmad | image =Ghulam Ahmad.JPG|center|200px|Ghulam Ahmad and Jamila Begum | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date =23 May 1923 | birth_place = [[Poonch]], [[Poonch district, Jammu and Kashmir|Poonch district]], [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|Kashmir and Jammu]], [[British India]] | death_date ={{Death date and age|df=yes|2003|09|20|1923|05|23}} | death_place = [[New Jersey]], United States | residence = [[Rawalakot]], [[Azad Kashmir|Pakistani Azad Kashmir]]. | citizenship = [[Pakistan]] | nationality = [[Pakistani people|Pakistani]] | ethnicity = [[Kashmiri]] | spouse = Jamila Begum | fields = Engineer | workplaces =[[Pakistan Forest Service]] (PFS)
[[Colorado Army National Guard|Colorado Department of Military Affairs]] (DMA)
[[Pakistan Chrome Mines Ltd]] (PCM)
[[Military Engineering Service]] (MES) |Alma mater = [[Delft University of Technology]]
[[Colorado State University]]
[[University of Punjab]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for =[[Environmental Science]]s | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} Shaikh '''Ghulam Ahmad''' (b. [[Poonch]], 23 May 1923 – d. [[New Jersey]], 20 September 2003) was a Pakistani forestry officialReport on Panjkora Valley forests Ghulam Ahmad - 1968 The Pakistan journal of forestry - Volume 22 - Page 71 Asad Ali Anvery (Saiyald), Pakistan Forest Institute - 1972 "No. F. 2(l5)/70-BG/1498 - dated 24th June, 1971. Mr. Ghulam Ahmad, P.F.S.I. Conservator of Forests, Aerial Forest Inventory Project, Pakistan Forest Institute, Peshawar is granted l3 days earned leave from 7th June, 197l to 19th June, 1971, ..." and later managing directorE & MJ international directory of mining - Page 554 1992 "AHMAD, GHULAM, Pakistan Chrome Mines Ltd. " and Chairman of [[Pakistan Chrome Mines Ltd]], the largest and oldest chrome mining company in Pakistan.Mining Industry in Pakistan 1952. Department of Mineral Concessions. Page 46{{Request quotation|date=March 2014}} In World War II he served in the [[Royal Indian Air Force]] as an [[Engineer Officer]], [[fighter pilot]] and [[military engineer]]. He also wrote ''Unique and Everliving'', a biography of the Islamic prophet, [[Muhammad]]. The book was written over a period of five years. The book is published by Ferozeson's Ltd., a book publisher in [[Pakistan]].[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1676480 National Library of Australia][http://openlibrary.org/works/OL5984053W/Unique_and_everliving OPEN LIBRARY] This book widely available in Libraries in the United States including the Library of Congresshttp://www.worldcat.org/title/unique-and-everliving/oclc/53360638 ==Life and education== He was born in the city of [[Poonch]], in [[Poonch District (J&K)|Poonch District]] of [[Kashmir]], on 23 May 1923. He was educated there at a school where his father, Shaikh Ghulam Rasul, was the headmaster. He migrated to [[Pakistan]] along with his family, during the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947. He married Jamila Begum at [[Rehara]], [[Azad Kashmir]], [[Pakistan]] on 11 May 1949. He had three sons and two daughters. His sons are Engineers while his daughters are doctors. His eldest daughter was the first female doctor from [[Rawalakot]]. She was also the first female Anesthesiologist from [[Azad Kashmir]] He received a B.Sc (honours) degree in Physics and a Masters in Statistics from the [[University of Punjab]] in [[Lahore]]. He received a Postgraduate Diploma in Natural Resource Development ITC, Delft, [[Netherlands]]. ==Career== [[File:Ghulam Ahmad RIAF.jpg|left|thumb|Ghulam Ahmad Royal Indian Air Force]] He joined the [[Royal Indian Air Force]] as a Fighter Pilot in the [[No. 1 Squadron, Indian Air Force]]. He fought against the [[Japanese Imperial Army]] in [[Burma]] during [[World War II]], flying in a [[Hawker Hurricane]] fighter plane. He was selected for the Forest Service after World War II and trained at the [[Forest Research Institute (India)|Forest Research Institute]] at [[Dehradun]], [[India]]. After the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947 he joined the Pakistan Forest Service, becoming the Chief Conservator of Forests and Director of the Aerial Survey Project in [[Peshawar]], Pakistan, where he surveyed the [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|North-West Frontier Province]] for a Natural Resources Survey from 1965-1969. He introduced hybrid poplars in Pakistan, including [[Azad Kashmir]], and especially [[Rawalakot]], changing the living conditions of the rural population. He supervised an aerial survey of the [[Indus River|Indus River Basin]] for the development of natural resources. He emigrated to the United States in August 1971 to complete a PhD in Civil Engineering at [[Colorado State University]], and joined the Colorado Department of Military Affairs, where he helped to draft the Emergency Response Plan for the State of [[Colorado]]. From 1983 until 1999 he was the Managing Director of [[Pakistan Chrome Mines Ltd]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmad, Ghulam}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:Pakistani businesspeople]] [[Category:Pakistani chief executives]] [[Category:People from Poonch district, India]] [[Category:University of the Punjab alumni]] [[Category:Colorado State University alumni]] [[Category:Pakistani foresters]]

{{Infobox cricketer | name = Harry Hole | image = | caption = | country = New Zealand | fullname = Henry Whitworth Hole | birth_date = {{Birth date|1855|12|10|df=yes}} | birth_place = Woolsey, near [[Crediton]], [[Devon]], [[England]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1942|6|23|1855|12|10|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Wanganui]], New Zealand | batting = | bowling = | family = | club1 = [[Nelson cricket team|Nelson]] | year1 = 1874-75 | columns = 1 | column1 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches1 = 1 | runs1 = 10 | bat avg1 = 5.00 | 100s/50s1 = 0/0 | top score1 = 6 | deliveries1 = 144 | wickets1 = 10 | bowl avg1 = 6.10 | fivefor1 = 1 | tenfor1 = 1 | best bowling1 = 8/37 | catches/stumpings1 = 0/0 | date = 19 August 2017 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/newzealand/content/player/37419.html Cricinfo }} '''Henry Whitworth "Harry" Hole''' (10 December 1855 – 23 June 1942) was a [[New Zealand]] [[cricketer]] who took 10 wickets on the first day of his only [[first-class cricket|first-class match]].
At the age of 19, Harry Hole was one of 10 players, five on each team, who were making their first-class debuts in the match between [[Nelson cricket team|Nelson]] and [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] at [[Victory Square, Nelson]], in February 1875. Wellington batted first, and Hole opened the bowling for Nelson. He bowled throughout the innings, taking 8 for 37 off 18 overs as Wellington were dismissed for 93. Nelson went in and made 100. Wellington batted again and were 40 for 5 at stumps on the first day. Hole again opened the bowling, and took the first two wickets but, "somewhat tired by his exertions", delivered only six overs before being relieved.<ref name="CA">{{cite web | url = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1926.html| title = Nelson v Wellington 1874-75| publisher = CricketArchive| subscription = yes | accessdate = 19 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | work=The Colonist | date=27 February 1875 | page=3 | title= Interprovincial Cricket Match: Wellington versus Nelson| url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TC18750227.2.8| volume=XVII | issue=1881}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | work=Nelson Evening Mail | date=27 February 1875 | page=2 | title= Cricket Match: Wellington v. Nelson | url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NEM18750227.2.8.1| volume=X | issue=50}}</ref> He did not bowl again in the match. Nelson dismissed Wellington for 71 and then made 65 for eight to win by two wickets.<ref name="CA"/><ref>{{cite news | work=The Colonist | date=2 March 1875 | page=3 | title= Interprovincial Cricket Match: Wellington v. Nelson – Second Day| url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TC18750302.2.11| volume=XVII | issue=1882}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | work=Nelson Evening Mail | date=1 March 1875 | page=2 | title= The Late Cricket Match| url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NEM18750301.2.11| volume=X | issue=51}}</ref> He is one of the six players in the history of first-class cricket to take 10 or more wickets in his only match.<ref>Keith Walmsley, ''Brief Candles'', ACS Publications, Cardiff, 2012, p. 83.</ref>
Harry Hole moved to the [[North Island]], where he ran hotels and general stores in [[Taupo]] and then Kerioi in the [[Wanganui]] area.<ref>{{cite news | work=Wanganui Chronicle | date=13 January 1888 | page=2 | title= Local and General| url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WC18880113.2.10| volume=XXXI | issue=11685}}</ref> He married Maggie Taylor in Wanganui on 23 December 1890.<ref>{{cite news | work=Wanganui Chronicle | date=24 December 1890 | page=2 | title= Local and General| url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WC18901224.2.9 | volume=XXXIII | issue=11152}}</ref> He entered the brewing business as a brewery manager in 1890 and became a partner with [[Hope Gibbons]] in the Wanganui Brewery in 1895.<ref>{{cite news | work=Wanganui Herald | date=29 September 1890 | page=3 | title= Advertisements| url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WH18900929.2.37.6 | volume=XXIV | issue=7226}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz/tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc01Cycl-t1-body-d4-d172-d25.html| title = Gibbons and Hole| publisher = The Cyclopedia of New Zealand [1897]| accessdate = 20 August 2017}}</ref>
In 1900 he lent his rural property at Tayforth, west of Wanganui, to the armed forces for several days of manoeuvres. About 1400 troops were involved.<ref>{{cite news | work=Wanganui Chronicle | date=20 April 1900 | page=2 | title= The Camp at Tayforth|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WC19000420.2.9}}</ref> By 1904 he had moved to a property north of [[Upokongaro]] on the [[Whanganui River]], where he farmed sheep.<ref>{{cite news | work=Wanganui Herald | date=23 November 1904 | page=7 | title= Round the District: Notes by "Rambler"| url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WH19041123.2.60| volume=XXXVIII | issue=11416}}</ref>
Apart from cricket he also played football and lawn bowls. In 1938, at 83, he was "the second oldest bowler in Wanganui".<ref>{{cite news | work=Evening Post | date=15 December 1938 | page=23 | title= Dominion Tourney| url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19381215.2.190.1 | volume=CXXVI | issue=144}}</ref>

{{infobox person |name=Harunur Rashid Khan Monno |native_name=হারুনুর রশিদ খান মুন্নু |native_name_lang=bn |nationality=Bangladeshi |birth_date= {{birth date|1932|8|17|df=y}} |death_place=[[Manikganj]], Bangladesh |death_date={{death date and age|2017|08|01|1932|8|17|df=y}} |occupation=Industrialist, politician }}
'''Harunur Rashid Khan Monno''' (17 August 1932 – 1 August 2017)<ref name=visionary>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/interview/harunur-rashid-khan-monno-the-visionary-behind-local-ceramics-1217500|title=Harunur Rashid Khan Monno - The visionary behind local ceramics|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=1 August 2017|newspaper=The Daily Star|first=Mehrin|last=Chowdhury}}</ref> was a Bangladeshi industrialist and politician. He served as the chairman of his [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]], Monno Group of Industries.<ref name=passes>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/politics/bnp-leader-haruner-rashid-khan-monno-passes-away-1441978|title=BNP’s Haruner Rashid Monno passes away|date=1 August 2017|accessdate=1 August 2017|newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref> He was elected a member of parliament<ref name=mp>{{cite news|url=http://www.parliament.gov.bd/index.php/en/mps/members-of-parliament/former-mp-s/list-of-7th-parliament-members-bangla|title=List of 7th Parliament Members|language=bn|accessdate=1 August 2017|publisher=Bangladesh Parliament}}</ref> and a minister of the [[Government of Bangladesh]]. He was also an adviser to [[Bangladesh National Party]] Chairperson [[Khaleda Zia]].<ref name=passes/>
==Career== While Monno was a student of [[chartered accountancy]], he joined [[Adamjee Haji Dawood]]'s company in the accounts department.<ref name=visionary/> His first assignment was to print export register copies for the Adamjee conglomerate company. Within two years, he established a press company of his own.<ref name=visionary/> Later he established Monno Group of Industries, which included [[Monno Ceramics]], Monno Jutex Industries, Monno Fabrics and Monno Attire Limited.<ref name=passes/> He received lifetime achievement award at the 16th Bangladesh Business Awards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/business/business-stars-awarded-1401274|title=Business stars awarded|date=5 May 2017|accessdate=1 August 2017|newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref>
Monno was elected as a member of parliament three times from the [[Manikganj-2]] constituency in 1991, 1996 and Manikganj-2, and [[Manikganj-3]] in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.ntvbd.com/bangladesh/143347/Former-lawmaker,-industrialist-Harunur-Rashid-Monno-dies|title=Former lawmaker, industrialist Harunur Rashid Monno dies|date=1 August 2017|accessdate=1 August 2017|publisher=NTV Bangladesh|first=Ahmed|last=Sohel}}</ref> In 2001, he was selected a cabinet member during the Khaleda Zia’s administration.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2017/08/01/industrialist-and-bnp-leader-harunur-rashid-khan-monno-dies|title=Industrialist and BNP leader Harunur Rashid Khan Monno dies|date=1 August 2017|accessdate=1 August 2017|publisher=bdnews24.com}}</ref> He lost the cabinet position in May 2003 when Zia was under pressure, especially from foreign donors, to downsize her cabinet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/general/bangladesh-cabinet-reshuffled-1.357172|title=Bangladesh cabinet reshuffled|date=23 May 2003|accessdate=1 August 2017|newspaper=Gulf News}}</ref>
==Personal life== Monno was married to Huron Nahar. Together they had two daughters – Afroza Khan Rita and Feroza Mahmud Parvin.<ref name=passes/> Afroza is serving as the Managing Director of Monno Group of Industries and also an adviser to Khaleda Zia.<ref name=passes/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.daily-sun.com/arcprint/details/157948/Family-connections-weigh-heavily-/2016-08-10|title=Family connections weigh heavily|date=10 August 2016|publisher=The Daily Sun|first=Mohammad|last=Amin|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> Feroza is married to journalist and businessman [[Mahmudur Rahman]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/11/always-in-headlines|title=Always in headlines|date=11 April 2013|accessdate=1 August 2017|publisher=bdnews24.com|first=Reazul|last=Bashar}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{more footnotes|date=February 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Likeresume|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Igor Vladimirovich Nak |image = Nak.jpg |birth_date = 6.08.1963 |birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[USSR]] |nationality = USSR, Russia |parents = Irina Alexandrovna Kuznetsova (born 1938)
[[Vladimir Nak]] (1935–2010) |children = Vladimir Nak (born 1985)
Grigoriy Nak (born 1990) |spouse = Elena Nak |awards = [[Russian Federation Presidential Certificate of Honour]] }} '''Igor Vladimirovich Nak''' (born on 6 August 1963, Moscow) is a Russian government and political figure, head of the [[United Russia|United Russia faction]] in the [[State Duma]] for the [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug]], head of the Council of the Deputy Faction, Chairman of the Coordinating Committee of the [[Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs]] in the [[Ural Federal District]], deputy of the [[Tyumen]] Regional Duma for the single electoral district from the United Russia political party, entrepreneur, general director of [[Yamaltransstroy|Yamaltransstroy JSC]], [[Kandidat]] of Technical Sciences, and Honorary Transport Engineer of Russia. ==Biography== Born on 6 August 1963 in the city of Moscow. In 1985, he graduated from the [[Moscow State University of Railway Engineering|Institute of Railway Transport of the Moscow Order of Lenin and Order of the Red Banner of Labour]], specializing in "Construction of Railways, Tracks and Track Facilities". In 2004, he defended his dissertation and received the academic degree of candidate of technical sciences. From 1985, he worked as expert and works manufacturer in construction and installation train No. 643 of the Moselectrotyagstroy trust. From 1986, he worked as works manufacturer, Deputy Head and Head in construction and installation train No. 351 of Yamaltransstroy manufacturing construction and installation union ([[Labytnangi|Labytnangi city]]). Since 1997, he was First Deputy then General Director of [[Yamaltransstroy|Yamaltransstroy JSC]], one of Russia's largest companies for railway construction above the Arctic Circle on the [[Yamal Peninsula]]. ==Political activities== From 1990 to 1994: elected deputy of the City Council of People's Deputies of Labytnangi city. From 1994 to 1997: deputy of the city Duma. From 1996 to 1997: deputy of the State Duma of the [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug]]. From 2000 to 2007: headed the Political Council of the Yamalo-Nenetsky regional branch of the Russian political party United Russia in the State Duma of the Autonomous Okrug, Head of the Council of the Deputy Faction.Article "Yamal United Russia holds election reporting conference" Since 2007: Head of the Yamalo-Nenetsky branch of the Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs/RSPP, Member of the Board of RSPP. In the same year, he was elected deputy of the Tyumen Oblast Duma for the single electoral district by the political party [[United Russia]].Article "United Russia approves candidates for Tyumen Oblast Duma" Since 2009: Chairman of the Presidium of the Coordinating Council of Associations of RSPP for the [[Ural Federal District]].⦁ Article "RSPP and Qatar Business Association sign memorandum of understanding" ==Honours and awards== Medal of the Order for Services to the Fatherland of 1st level (22 October 2011) ''for achieving successes in work and many years of productive work''. Decree of the President of the Russian Federation #1408 from 22 October 2011 Medal of the Order for Services to the Fatherland of the 2nd level (9 March 1996).Decree of the President of the Russian Federation No. 360 from 9 March 1996 Honorary Charter of the President of the Russian Federation (14 August 2013) ''for achieving successes in work, active community undertakings and many years of conscientious work''.Order of the President of the Russian Federation #302-рп from 14 August 2013 ”On promotion" Badge of Honorary Transport Engineer (16 August 1994) ''for a large contribution to the social and economic development of the Yamalo-Nenetsky Autonomous Okrug and in connection with the 65th anniversary of its foundation.'' Badge of Honorary Transport Engineer (6 August 2008) ''for many years of productive work and large contribution to the development of transport construction''. Russian Orthodox Church's Order of the Venerable Sergei of Radonezh of the 3rd level (19 June 2007) ''for providing assistance to Tobolsk Theological Schools''. Honorary Charter of the State Duma of the Yamalo-Nenetrsky Autonomous Okrug (26 September 2003) ''for achievements in the area of transport construction on the Yamal Peninsula and high quality of executed work (Ministry of Construction of the Russian Federation)''.Resolution of the State Duma of the Yamalo-Nenetsky Autonomous Okrug #1045 from 26 September 2003 Honorary Charter of the Chairman of the Federal Council of the Federal Assembly of the Russian Federation (6 December 2005) ''for conscientious work, large contribution to the development of legislation of the Yamalo-Nenetsky Okrug, strengthening of democracy, and also in connection with the 75th anniversary of the foundation of the Yamalo-Nenetsky Autonomous Okrug''. Honorary Charter of the Tyumen Oblast Duma (20 December 2007) ''for many years of conscientious work and significant contribution to the socio-economic development of Tyumen Oblast''. Honorary Charter (7 May 2007) ''for productive and effective work in the post of Secretary of the Political Council of the Yamalo-Nenetsky branch of the United Russia political party''. Honorary Charter of the Governor of Tyumen Oblast (7 April 2009) ''for significant contribution to the development of legislation of Tyumen Oblast, many years of conscientious work and in connection with the 15th anniversary of the foundation of the Tyumen Oblast Duma''. Honorary Charter (10 December 2010) ''for many years of conscientious work, large contribution to the socio-economic development of the Yamalo-Nenetsky Autonomous Okrug, and in connection with the 25th anniversary of the foundation of Yamaltransstroy JSC'' (Ruling of the Legislative Assembly of the Yamalo-Nenetsky Autonomous Okrug). Honorary Charter (23 December 2010) ''for significant contribution to the development of legislation of the Russian Federation and parliamentarianism in the Russian Federation'' (Order of the Chairman of the State Duma). Honorary Charter of the Ministry of Economic Development of the Russian Federation (12 April 2010) ''for active participation in the development and implementation of social and economic policy based on public-private partnership''. Badge from the Russian Trade Union of Railwaymen and Transport Engineers "For Development of Social Partnership" (15 June 2010) ''for a large contribution to the development of transport construction, productive work in defending the socio-economic interests of workers, and strengthening the social partnership with the Russian Trade Union of Railwaymen and Transport Engineers.'' Golden Badge of the [[Moscow State University of Railway Engineering|Moscow Institute of Transport Engineers]] (31 August 2010).Order of the Federal Agency of Railway Transport of the Moscow State Museum of Communications #230/но from 31 August 2010 ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nak, Igor}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:United Russia politicians]] [[Category:21st-century Russian politicians]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]]

{{Infobox ambassador |name = Jorge Visbal Martelo |image = |imagesize = |alt = |order = |ambassador_from = Colombia |country = Peru |term_start = 2 February 2011 |term_end = |predecessor = María Claudia Mosquera Jaramillo |successor = |president = [[Juan Manuel Santos Calderón]] |office2 = [[Senator of Colombia]] |term_start2 = 3 June 2007 |term_end2 = 29 May 2009 |predecessor2 = [[Luis Guillermo Vélez Trujillo]] |ambassador_from3 = Colombia |country3 = Canada |term_start3 = 2 September 2004 |term_end3 = September 2005 |predecessor3 = Fanny Kertzman Yankelevitch |successor3 = [[Jaime Girón Duarte]] |president3 = [[Álvaro Uribe Vélez]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|06|26|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Corozal, Sucre|Corozal]], [[Sucre Department|Sucre]], [[Colombia]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Colombian people|Colombian]] |party = [[Party of the U]] <small>(2006-present) |spouse = |children = |alma_mater = [[Universidad Externado de Colombia|Externado University]] <small>([[BBA]], 1983) |religion = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = |footnotes = }} {{Spanish name|Visbal|Martelo}}
'''Jorge Aníbal Visbal Martelo''' (born 26 June 1953) is the current [[Ambassador of Colombia to Peru]].
==Ambassador to Canada== On 13 July 2004,<ref name="named">{{cite web |title=Jorge Visbal Martelo, Nuevo Embajador en Canadá |trans-title=Jorge Visbal Martelo, New Ambassador to Canada |date=2004-07-13 |accessdate=2011-08-29 |language=Spanish |url=http://www.presidencia.gov.co/prensa_new/sne/2004/julio/14/13142004.htm |publisher=Press Office of the President of Colombia (SNE) |location=Bogotá }}</ref> [[President of Colombia|President]] [[Álvaro Uribe Vélez]] named Visbal [[Ambassador of Colombia to Canada]]; this was the first political appointment for Visbal who had been serving as President of the Colombian Federation of Cattle Ranchers (Fedegan) since 1991.<ref name="named"/> He was sworn in on July 16,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidencia.gov.co/prensa_new/sne/2004/julio/16/03162004.htm |trans-title='I Will Sell The Good Face of Colombia':Visbal Martelo |title='Venderé la Cara Buena de Colombia': Visbal Martelo |publisher=Press Office of the President of Colombia (SNE) |accessdate=2011-08-29 |language=Spanish |location=Bogotá }}</ref> and presented his [[Letters of Credence]] to [[The Right Honourable]] [[Adrienne Clarkson]], [[Governor General of Canada]], in a ceremony at [[Citadelle of Quebec|La Citadelle]] in [[Quebec City]] on September 2.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Diplomatic Circles |first=Christina |last=Leadlay |date=2004-09-08 |accessdate=2011-08-29 |magazine=Diplomat |location=Ottawa |url=http://www.embassymag.ca/page/view/.2004.september.8.dip_circ }}</ref>
==Senator of Colombia== In late 2005 it was announced that Ambassador Visbal would resign to run for Congress in the [[Colombian legislative election, 2006|2006 legislative elections]], but fail to earn a seat in Congress. In 2007 however, following the death of Senator [[Luis Guillermo Vélez Trujillo]] a [[Party of the U]] politician, Visbal was selected by the party to replace him in Congress as a [[Senator of Colombia]].
==Ambassador to Peru== In 2010, President [[Juan Manuel Santos Calderón]] appointed Visbal Ambassador to the neighboring nation of [[Peru]], and on January 21, 2011, before the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Colombia)|Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs]] Mónica Lanzetta Mutis, Visbal was sworn in as [[Ambassador of Colombia to Peru]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wsp.presidencia.gov.co/Prensa/2011/Enero/Paginas/20110121_05.aspx |accessdate=2011-08-29 |language=Spanish |publisher=Press Office of the President of Colombia (SGI) |location=Bogotá |title=Jorge Visbal Martelo se posesionó como Embajador de Colombia en Perú |trans-title=Jorge Visbal Martelo was sworn in as Ambassador of Colombia to Peru }}</ref> He travelled that same month to Peru, where he met with [[Ministry of Foreign Relations (Peru)|Peruvian Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[José García Belaúnde]] to whom he presented preliminary copies of his credentials in a meeting at the [[Torre Tagle Palace]] on January 31 before officially presenting his Letters of Credence on February 2 to [[President of Peru|President]] [[Alan García]] in a ceremony of protocol at the [[Government Palace (Peru)|Government Palace]] in [[Lima]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/Noticia.aspx?Id=Oi3yvYlRl+8= |journal=[[ATV (Peruvian Network)|Andina]] |title=Peruvian president receives credentials from Colombian, Czech ambassadors |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-08-29 |location=Lima }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.co/wps/portal/embajada_peru/!ut/p/c0/04_SB8K8xLLM9MSSzPy8xBz9CP0os_jQsKAwo2AXYwMDA0dzA08TC1PzYD8vIxN_c_2CbEdFAJqkvlo!/?WCM_PORTLET=PC_7_UVRV2SD30GD8A0IH4624EQ1Q14_WCM&WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/wps/wcm/connect/WCM_PRENSA/prensa/entrevistas/entrevista+del+canciller+con+el+espectador |title=Presentación Copia de Cartas Credenciales |trans-title=Presentation of Copy of Letters of Credence |publisher=Embassy of Colombia in Peru |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-08-29 |location=Lima |language=Spanish}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
