'''Limerick Chamber of Commerce''' was founded in 1805 and was formally constituted by Charter on 2 June 1815. It was one of the five oldest [[Chamber of commerce|Chambers of Commerce]] in Ireland and the UK at the time of its foundation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://limerickchamber.ie/about-us/|title=About Us {{!}} Limerick Chamber|website=limerickchamber.ie|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-01}}</ref>
Limerick Chamber is a business representative and lobbying organisation that is in business for its 450+ members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.limerick.ie/business/how-we-help/business-supports/limerick-chamber|title=Limerick Chamber {{!}} Limerick.ie|website=www.limerick.ie|language=en|access-date=2018-06-01}}</ref>
The CEO since 2015 is Dr James Ring. Presidents are elected annually.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.limerickpost.ie/2018/04/17/ceo-of-limerick-chamber-departs-in-order-to-take-up-new-role/|title=CEO of Limerick Chamber departs in order to take up new role|date=2018-04-17|work=Limerick Post Newspaper|access-date=2018-06-01|language=en-GB}}</ref> Past Presidents included businessmen [[Alexander William Shaw]], [[Thomas Cleeve]], Irish politician [[Ted Russell (Irish politician)|Ted Russell]], Irish Conservative politician [[James Spaight (MP)|James Spaight]] and his father [[Francis Spaight]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://limerickchamber.ie/limerick-chamber-presidents/|title=Presidents {{!}} Limerick Chamber|website=limerickchamber.ie|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>
In 2015: Limerick Chamber has published a book entitled ‘Limerick’s Merchants, Traders & Shakers – ''Celebrating two centuries of enterprise''’ by [[Matthew Potter]] and [[Sharon Slater]] to mark its 200th Anniversary.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Limerick's Merchants, Traders and Shakers|last=Potter|first=Matthew|last2=Slater|first2=Sharon|publisher=Limerick Chamber|year=2015|isbn=9780953835416|location=Limerick|pages=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:Limerick (city)]]

{{Contract law}} '''Liquidated damages''' (also referred to as liquidated and ascertained damages) are damages whose amount the parties designate during the formation of a [[contracts|contract]]<ref name= Liquidated>{{Cite web | url = http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Liquidated+damages | title = Liquidated Damages | format = w | accessdate = 2012-12-18 }}</ref> for the injured party to collect as compensation upon a specific breach (e.g., late performance).<ref name= "Liquidated" />
When damages are not predetermined/assessed in advance, then the amount recoverable is said to be 'at large' (to be agreed or determined by a court or tribunal in the event of breach).
==Common law==
Generally, at [[common law]], a liquidated damages clause will not be enforced if its purpose is to punish the wrongdoer/party in breach rather than to compensate the injured party<ref>{{cite BAILII |court=UKHL |year=1914 |num=1 |litigants=Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd v New Garage & Motor Co Ltd |parallelcite=[1915] [[Appeal Cases Law Reports|AC]] 79}}.</ref><ref name="Amev-Udc">{{cite AustLII|HCA|63|1986|litigants=Amev-Udc Finance Ltd v Austin |parallelcite=(1986) 162 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 170 |courtname=auto |date=}}.</ref><ref name="Plessnig ">{{cite AustLII|HCA|7|1989|litigants=Esanda Finance Corp v Plessnig |parallelcite=(1989) 166 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 131 |courtname=auto |date=}}.</ref> (in which case it is referred to as a [[penal damages|penal or penalty clause]]).<ref name= "Liquidated damages, penalties and the Just Compensation rule: Some notes on an enforcement model and a theory of efficient breach" >{{Cite journal | url = https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/1121823?uid=3738776&uid=2&uid=4&sid=21100860664611 | title = Liquidated damages, penalties and the Just Compensation rule: Some notes on an enforcement model and a theory of efficient breach | journal = Columbia Law Review | volume = 77 | format = w | accessdate = 2012-12-19 }}</ref> One reason for this is that the enforcement of the term would, in effect, require an equitable order of [[specific performance]]. However, courts sitting in [[Equity (law)|equity]] will seek to achieve a fair result and will not enforce a term that will lead to the [[unjust enrichment]] of the enforcing party.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://law.jrank.org/pages/8310/Liquidated-Damages.html | title = Liquidated Damages | journal = American Law Encyclopedia | volume = 6 | format = w | accessdate = 2009-04-07 }}</ref>
In order for a liquidated damages clause to be upheld, two conditions must be met. * First, the amount of the damages identified must roughly approximate the damages likely to fall upon the party seeking the benefit of the term.<ref name= "Liquidated damages, penalties and the Just Compensation rule: Some notes on an enforcement model and a theory of efficient breach" /> * Second, the damages must be sufficiently uncertain at the time the contract is made that such a clause will likely save both parties the future difficulty of estimating damages. Damages that are sufficiently uncertain may be referred to as '''unliquidated damages''', and may be so categorized because they are not mathematically calculable or are subject to a [[contingent liability|contingency]] which makes the amount of damages uncertain.
===Example=== For example, suppose Neal Townsend agrees to lease a store-front to Richard Smith, from which Richard intends to sell jewellery. If Townsend breaches the contract by refusing to lease the store-front at the appointed time, it will be difficult to determine what profits Smith will have lost because the success of newly created small businesses is highly uncertain. This, therefore, would be an appropriate circumstance for Smith to insist upon a liquidated damages clause in case Townsend fails to perform.
In the case of construction contracts, courts have occasionally refused to enforce liquidated damages provisions, choosing to follow the [[doctrine of concurrent delay]] when both parties have contributed to the overall delay of the project.
Contracts in the [[NEC Engineering and Construction Contract|NEC3]] family use the term 'low service damages' (optional clause X.17) and generally include a Low Service Damages Schedule.<ref>[[Institute of Workplace and Facilities Management|British Institute of Facilities Management]], Getting Started with the NEC3 Term Services Contract, accessed 23 June 2015</ref>
===The definition and scope extended=== In Australia, the definition of liquidated damages applies to the situations where upon the failure of a primary stipulation, imposes a detriment to the first party or a benefit to the second party by a secondary stipulation collateral to the primary stipulation (i.e. it does not have to be a breach).<ref name="Andrews">{{cite AustLII|HCA|30|2012|litigants=Andrews v Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited |parallelcite= }}. {{cite web|url=http://www.hcourt.gov.au/assets/publications/judgment-summaries/2012/hca30-2012-09-06.pdf |title=judgment summary |publisher=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]] (Australia) |date=6 September 2012}}</ref>
===The law applied to bank and credit card charges=== UK bank and credit card customers were being charged as much as £39 for a single transaction that took them over their credit limit. Consumers argued these charges were well beyond the cost of sending a computerised letter.
In 2007 the [[Office of Fair Trading]] investigated the charges being imposed on customers of credit card companies. In its report, the OFT claimed these charges were unlawful under UK law as they amounted to a penalty. It said it would be prepared to investigate any charge over £12, though this was not intended to indicate that £12 is a fair and acceptable charge. The OFT said it would be up to a court to determine such an amount based on the established legal precedent that the only recoverable cost would be actual costs incurred.
The credit card companies did not produce evidence of their actual costs to the OFT, instead insisting their charges are in line with clear policy and information provided to customers.
Receipt of liquidated damages and intimately linked with the purpose of the profit-making apparatus, is a capital receipt. The amount received by the assessee towards compensation for seterilization of the profit earning source is not in the ordinary course of business. Hence, it is a capital receipt in the hands of the assessee.
In 2009 the Supreme Court ruled (''see [[Office of Fair Trading v Abbey National plc]]'') that terms in bank account contracts were not capable of being penal, bar those applicable to NatWest Bank customers between 2001 and 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oft.gov.uk/news/press/2008/55-08 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123082125/http://oft.gov.uk/news/press/2008/55-08 |archivedate=2009-01-23 |df= }}</ref> The court ruled that the charges were a charge for a service, and not a penalty for damages for breaching a contract term.
===Bank Fees===
In 2012, the High Court of Australia allowed an appeal against findings of the Federal Court of Australia that 'exception fees' imposed by the ANZ Bank could not constitute an unenforceable penalty. The High Court found that fees were not incapable of being characterised as penalties merely because they were not charged upon breach of contract.<ref name="Andrews"/>
Conversely, in 2014, the federal court (Gordon J) described $35 late payment fees by ANZ Banking Group to customers who failed to make their monthly minimum credit card repayment as being “extravagant, exorbitant and unconscionable” and ordered for these fees to be reimbursed.<ref>{{cite AustLII|FCA|35|2014|litigants=Paciocco v Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited |parallelcite= |courtname=auto |date=5 February 2014}}.</ref> ANZ appealed.
In 2015, the full court overturned Justice Gordon’s first instance judgment that credit card late payment fees charged by ANZ to its customers constituted penalties at law and equity (and were therefore largely unenforceable).<ref>{{cite AustLII|FCAFC|78|2015|litigants=Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited v Paciocco |parallelcite= |courtname=auto |date=5 June 2015}}.</ref> The decision otherwise upholds Justice Gordon's findings that honour, dishonour and overlimit fees charged by ANZ were not penalties, unconscionable or unfair. While the decision is very fact specific, it represented a major setback for other class actions based on penalties. Paciocco appealed to the High Court.
The last chapter of the bank fees saga took place in July 2016 where the High Court dismissed the appeal for leave and held that the full court was correct to characterise the loss provision costs, regulatory capital costs and collection costs as affecting the legitimate interests of the Bank.<ref name="Paccioco">{{cite AustLII|HCA|28|2016|litigants=Paccioco v Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited |parallelcite= }} {{cite web|url=http://www.hcourt.gov.au/assets/publications/judgment-summaries/2016/hca-28-2016-07-27.pdf |title=judgment summary |publisher=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]] (Australia) |date=27 July 2016}}</ref> The Court asserted that the fact that those categories of costs could not be recovered in an action for damages did not alter that conclusion. Further, neither the fact that the late payment fees were not genuine pre-estimates of damage nor the fact that the amounts charged were disproportionate to the actual loss suffered by itself rendered the late payment fees penalties. [http://www.hcourt.gov.au/assets/publications/judgment-summaries/2016/hca-28-2016-07-27.pdf High Court]
==Uniform Commercial Code==
In the United States, Section 2-718(1) of the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] provides that, in contracts for the sale of goods:<ref>{{cite web|title=§ 2-718. Liquidation or Limitation of Damages; Deposits.|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/ucc/2/2-718|publisher=Legal Information Institute|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
:Damages for breach by either party may be liquidated in the agreement but only at an amount which is reasonable in the light of the anticipated or actual harm caused by the breach, the difficulties of proof of loss, and the inconvenience or nonfeasibility of otherwise obtaining an adequate remedy. A term fixing unreasonably large liquidated damages is void as a penalty.
This largely mirrors the common law rule, which applies to other types of contracts under the law of most US states.
==Other legal systems==
===Civil law===
[[Civil law (legal system)|Civil law]] systems generally impose less severe restrictions on liquidated damages. For example, Article 1226 of the [[French Civil Code]] provides for ''clause pénale'', a variant of liquidated damages which combines compensatory and coercive elements. Judges may adjust excessive contract penalties, but such clauses are not generally void as a matter of French law.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clarke|first1=Joanne|title="Clause pénale" v. liquidated damages – any similarities?|url=http://kluwerconstructionblog.com/2010/02/24/%E2%80%9Cclause-penale%E2%80%9D-v-liquidated-damages-any-similarities/|website=Kluwer Construction Blog|accessdate=17 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402121351/http://kluwerconstructionblog.com/2010/02/24/%E2%80%9Cclause-penale%E2%80%9D-v-liquidated-damages-any-similarities/|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}}</ref>
Article 420-1 of the [[Civil Code of Japan]] provides an even firmer basis to uphold contractual penalties:<ref>{{cite web|title=Civil Code|url=http://www.moj.go.jp/content/000056024.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Justice (Japan)|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
# The parties may agree on the amount of the liquidated damages with respect to the failure to perform the obligation. In such case, the court may not increase or decrease the amount thereof. # The liquidated damages shall not preclude the demand for performance or the exercise of the cancellation right. # Any penalty is presumed to constitute liquidated damages.
In the U.S. state of [[Louisiana]], which follows a civil law system, liquidated damages are referred to as "stipulated damages".<ref>[[Louisiana Civil Code]], Article 2005: Parties may stipulate the damages to be recovered in case of nonperformance, defective performance, or delay in performance of an obligation. http://legis.la.gov/Legis/LawSearchList.aspx accessed 23 June 2015</ref> Prior to 1 January 1985, Louisiana law used the term “penal clause” under former article 2117 of the [[Louisiana Civil Code|Civil Code]].<ref>Louisiana Court of Appeal, Second Circuit, Mary Mobley v. Gary Mobley, No. 37,364-CA {{cite web |url=http://www.lex.uniba.it/ta/clausola%20penale%20louisiana%20court%20of%20appeal.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623073715/http://www.lex.uniba.it/ta/clausola%20penale%20louisiana%20court%20of%20appeal.pdf |archivedate=2015-06-23 |df= }}</ref> Stipulated damages create a secondary obligation for the purpose of enforcing the principal obligation. The aggrieved party may demand either the stipulated damages or performance of the principal obligation, but may not demand both except for delay.<ref>Louisiana Civil Code, Article 2007 http://legis.la.gov/Legis/Law.aspx?d=109263 accessed 23 June 2015</ref> Stipulated damages may not be modified by the court (and will therefore be enforced) "unless they are so manifestly unreasonable as to be contrary to public policy".<ref>Louisiana Civil Code, Article 2012 http://legis.la.gov/Legis/Law.aspx?d=109269 accessed 23 June 2015. See also {{cite web|last1=Isom|first1=H. Chervis|title=Specific Performance: The Importance of a Clear Liquidated Damage Provision|url=http://www.bakerdonelson.com/specific-performance-the-importance-of-a-clear-liquidated-damage-provision-01-03-2007/|publisher=Baker Donelson|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
===Islamic law===
[[Islamic law]] prohibits ''[[gharar]]'' (uncertainty) in contracts, and liquidated damages provisions are a favored mechanism to overcome uncertainty regarding contractual damages.<ref>{{cite web|title=Islamic Contract Law|url=http://www.saudilegal.com/saudilaw/02_law.html|website=Saudilegal|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
see also {{cite BAILII |litigants=Cavendish Square Holding BV v Talal El Makdessi |year=2015 |court=UKSC |num=67 |courtname=auto}}
==See also== *[[Unspecified claim]] * [[Penal bond]]
[[Category:Contract law]] [[Category:Judicial remedies]]

In employment law, a '''Loudermill letter''' is a letter that public-sector employers may send to employees giving notice of their intent to suspend, demote, or terminate.
According to [[Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill]], the process that is due a public employee includes a pre-termination hearing that provides "oral or written notice of the charges against him, an explanation of the employer's evidence, and an opportunity to present his side of the story." The Loudermill letter fulfills the requirement of (written) notice, and should include an explanation of the employer's evidence ("to act as a check for mistaken accusations"). To fulfill the remaining [[Due Process]] requirements, a Loudermill letter will also have to inform the employee of his opportunity for a [[Loudermill hearing]].
==Content of the letter==
The formal letter advising the employee that discipline is being considered, and offering the opportunity for the employee to discuss or present his or her version and mitigating evidence, may be the first time the employee is even aware that certain allegations have arisen or that an investigation has been concluded.
The letter usually states that the employee may contact his union representative. The governing contract language may also state that the union representative will receive a copy of the letter
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110725131823/http://www.vermontpersonnel.org/employee/policy/pm81.htm A sample Loudermill letter]
[[Category:Labour law]]

''''Marketing intelligence''' ('''MI''') is the everyday information relevant to a company’s markets, gathered and analyzed specifically for the purpose of accurate and confident decision-making in determining market opportunity, market penetration strategy, and market development metrics. Marketing intelligence is necessary when entering a foreign market.
Marketing intelligence determines the intelligence needed, collects it by searching environment and delivers it to marketing managers who need it. Marketing intelligence software can be deployed using an on-premises or [[software as a service]] (SaaS, or cloud-based) model. These systems take data from disparate data sources, like [[web analytics]], [[business intelligence]], call center and sales data, which often come separate reports, and put them into a single environment. In order to collect marketing intelligence, marketing managers must be in constant touch with relevant books, newspapers and trade publications. They must talk to various stakeholders like customers, distributors, and suppliers. In addition to this, they must also monitor social media and carry out online discussions. Marketing managers can design reports that correlate and visualize data coming from a variety of departments and sources (even, in some cases, external data.) This allows them to see current [[key performance indicators]] in real time (or as quickly as sources provide data) and analyze trends, rather than wait for analysts to deliver periodic reports.
Marketing intelligence systems are designed to be used by marketing managers and often viewed by employees throughout an organization. Notable systems on the market include Leadtime, Pardot, Marketo, and Hubspot. They may have [[user interfaces]] that closely resemble consumer software than the software around individual data sources, which are designed for use by analysts. Business intelligence, for example, can collect highly accurate, timely, granular data, but often requires IT support to build and edit custom reports.
Organizationally, marketing intelligence can be the name of the department that performs both the market intelligence and competitor analysis roles. Business intelligence of any kind may also be their responsibility, in tandem with (or solely performed by) the Finance department, for measuring market share and setting growth targets, the [[mergers and acquisitions]] group for exploring acquisition opportunities, the legal department to protect the organization's assets or [[research and development]] for cross-company comparison of innovation trends and the discovery of opportunities through innovative differentiation.
Steps to be taken by a Company to improve its Marketing Intelligence
(1) Train and Motivate Sales Force: A company's sales force can be an excellent source of information about the current trends in the market. They are the "intelligence gatherers" for the company. The acquired facts can be regarding the company's market offerings, whether any improvements are required or not or is there any opportunity for new products, etc. It can also provide a credible source to know about competitor activities, consumers, distributors, and retailers.
(2) Motivate Distributors, retailers, and other intermediaries to pass along important intelligence: Specialists are hired by companies to gather marketing intelligence. In order to measure the quality of production, the way the employees are behaving with customers, quality of facilities being provided; retailers and service providers send mystery shoppers. Firms can also assess the quality of customer experience with the shops with the use of mystery shoppers.
(3) Network Externally: Every firm must keep a tab on its competitors. [[Competitive intelligence]] describes the broader discipline of researching, analyzing and formulating data and information from the entire competitive environment of any organization. This can be done by purchasing the competitor's products, checking the advertising campaigns, the press media coverage, reading their published reports, etc. Competitive intelligence must be legal and ethical.
(4) Set up a customer advisory panel: Companies can set up panels consisting of customers. They can be the company's largest customers or representatives of customers or the most outspoken customers. Many business schools set up panels consisting of alumni who provide their knowledge and expertise and help in constituting the course curriculum.
(5) Optimal usage of Government data resources: Governments of almost all countries publish reports regarding the population trends, demographic characteristics, agricultural production and a lot of other such data. All this data must be or can be referred to as base data. It can help in planning and formulating policies for the companies.
(6) Information bought from external suppliers: Certain agencies sell data that can be useful to other companies. For example, television channels will require information on the number of viewership, ratings of TV programs, etc. An agency which calculates this information and generates this data will provide it to companies that need it.
(7) Collect Competitive Intelligence through online customer feedback: Customer's view about a product is essential for any company. Ultimately it's the customer who's buying the product. Hence customer feedback must be taken. Online platforms like chat rooms, blogs, discussion forums, customer review boards can be used to generate customer feedback. This enables the firm to understand customer experiences and impressions. It becomes easier for companies to apply a structured system to do so as it can then scan out the relevant messages without much of a trouble.
With the above steps being applied, a company's marketing intelligence system will prove to be beneficial to its effective functioning.
== References == * Kotler, Keller, Koshy and Jha (2009). "Marketing Management, 13th Edition",Chapter 3, Page 64 to 67. == Related Articles == *[[Media intelligence]] *[[Customer Data Platform]]
==External links== * [https://externalinsights.com/resources/17-what-is-market-intelligence/ Externalinsights.com - What Is Market Intelligence?] * [https://externalinsights.com/resources/24-the-importance-of-market-intelligence/ Externalinsights.com - The Importance Of Market Intelligence?]
[[Category:Market research]]

{{Infobox person | name = Markus Jooste | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Markus Johannes Jooste | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|01|22}} | birth_place = Pretoria | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = South African | residence = [[Stellenbosch]], South Africa | education = [[Afrikaanse Hoër Seunskool]] (Affies) | alma mater = [[Stellenbosch University]], [[University of Cape Town]] | occupation = Businessman | title = Former CEO, [[Steinhoff International]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = US$400 million (December 2016)<ref name="Forbes" /> | spouse = Ingrid Jooste | parents = | children = 3 | relations = | website = }}
'''Markus Johannes Jooste''' (born 22 January 1961)<ref name="styan">{{cite book |last1=Styan |first1=James-Brent |title=Steinhoff en die Stellenbosse boys |date=2018 |publisher=LAPA Uitgewers |isbn=9780799371635}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/MRjrIvkfM8rqVRz5xVuOkLXYQ-8/appointments|title=Markus Johannes JOOSTE – Personal Appointments (free information from Companies House)|work= companieshouse.gov.uk |accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref> is a South African businessman and the former CEO of [[Steinhoff International]]. He is an avid horse breeder, and in 2016 was reported to be one of Africa's richest people, worth $400 million.<ref name="Forbes">{{cite web|title=Markus Jooste |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/markus-jooste/ |website=Forbes |accessdate=14 December 2016}}</ref><ref name =news24a/> Joining forces with [[Christo Wiese]] in 2014, they embarked on an aggressive international expansion programme.<ref name="ing">{{cite web |last1=Ingham |first1=Mark N |last2=Hogg |first2=Alec |title=Ingham's Incisive Insights: Mark Ingham assesses Steinhoff: Top SA entrepreneurs combine to make magic |url=https://www.fin24.com/BizNews/mark-ingham-assesses-steinhoff-top-sa-entrepreneurs-combine-to-make-magic-20160926 |website=fin24.com |date = 26 September 2016 |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref> Jooste's sudden resignation from Steinhoff on 5 December 2017 was followed by an involved and protracted controversy concerning Steinhoff's accounting practices in its Central European business dating back to 2016,<ref name="turner">{{cite news |last1=Turner |first1=Nick |last2=Pfanner |first2=Eric |title= Christo Wiese quits board as Steinhoff scandal deepens |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/steinhoff-chair-will-quit-supervisory-board-after-scandal-20171214 |accessdate= 13 June 2018 |agency=fin24.com |date=14 December 2017}}</ref> or even 2014.<ref name="cronje2">{{cite news |last1=Cronje |first1=Jan |title= Steinhoff accounting scandal may date back to at least 2014 - reports |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/steinhoff-accounting-scandal-may-date-back-to-at-least-2014-reports-20180301 |accessdate=13 June 2018 |agency=fin24.com |date=1 March 2018}}</ref> The resulting uncertainty saw some €10 billion (R160 billion) of Steinhoff's value wiped off the markets in a matter of days,<ref name="turner"/> with further losses as the situation unfolded.
==Early life== Jooste's father was a postal worker and an avid [[horse racing|horse race]] punter, instilling also in his son an interest in the races.<ref name =news24a/><ref name="mg1"/> Jooste matriculated from [[Afrikaanse Hoër Seunskool]] in 1978.<ref name="insider1">{{cite web |last1=de Wet |first1=Phillip |title=Steinhoff’s Markus Jooste gave his old school R10 million, but no-one wants to touch it |url= https://www.businessinsider.co.za/affies-ringfenced-r10-million-from-markus-jooste-of-steinhoff-2018-2 |website= businessinsider.co.za |publisher=Business Insider SA |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> Before the 2017 fallout in his business empire, he donated R10 million to the school's old-boys trust in his personal capacity. The donation has since been ring-fenced pending possible claims.<ref name="insider1"/>
He obtained a BAcc degree from [[Stellenbosch University]] in 1982,<ref name="bloom3">{{cite web |title=Markus Johannes Jooste |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=8596826&privcapId=22533711 |website=Company Overview of Steinhoff Europe AG: Executive Profile |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> and subsequently obtained an honours degree<ref name="biznews.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.biznews.com/entrepreneur/2016/06/03/markus-jooste-on-losing-bids-building-steinhoff-and-drawing-inspiration/ |title=Markus Jooste - On losing bids, building Steinhoff and drawing inspiration. - BizNews.com|date=3 June 2016 |work=biznews.com |accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref> at the [[University of Cape Town]] while completing his CA(SA) articles at a company then owned by [[Christo Wiese]].<ref name="ns1"/><!--details still vague here-->
==Career== After training as a chartered accountant in his 20s,<ref name="biznews.com"/> he was appointed financial director of a publicly listed company. At age 27 he became the financial director of GommaGomma, where he met German entrepreneur [[Claas Daun]], who coached him in business.<ref name =news24a/> On his part, Jooste convinced Daun in 1998 to merge his business with that of [[Bruno Steinhoff]] in Europe, and to list [[Steinhoff International]] on the JSE.<ref name="ah1">{{cite web |last1=Hogg |first1=Alec |title=The Steinhoff story – revisiting the humble roots of today’s R260bn giant |url= https://www.biznews.com/sa-investing/2015/06/19/the-steinhoff-story-revisiting-humble-roots-of-a-r260bn-giant/ |website=BizNews |publisher= biznews.com | date = 19 June 2015 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> Jooste and Daun acted as non-executive directors of Steinhoff International from 1988,<ref name="ns1">{{cite news |last1= Schreuder |first1= Nica |title=8 things you didn’t know about former Steinhoff CEO Markus Jooste |url= https://citizen.co.za/news/news-cns/1753566/8-things-you-didnt-know-about-former-steinhoff-ceo-markus-jooste/|accessdate=25 December 2017 |work=Business |agency=The Citizen |publisher=citizen.co.za |date=8 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="pc1"/> and Jooste became its CEO in 2000. In his role as CEO, he built the company through numerous acquisitions from a small furniture manufacturer to a large corporation in the furniture industry. Piet Ferreira, a former investment banker who joined Steinhoff in 2002, was instrumental in structuring its public offerings and complex acquisitions during his 15 year tenure.<ref name="zarx1">{{cite web |title=ZXTWI - Change to Board of Directors: Appointment of Independent Non-executive Director |url= https://www.zarx.co.za/news/detail/change-to-board-of-directors-ZXTWI-20170703-01 |website=zarx.co.za| date = 3 July 2017 |accessdate= 29 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="mg3">{{cite web |last1=Greig |first1=Marylou |title=Individual DealMaker of the Year – 2016 |url= https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/individual-dealmaker-of-the-year-2016/ |website= moneyweb.co.za |date= 10 February 2017 |accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>
Notably, they acquired [[Conforama]] in 2011 for €1,207-million,<ref name="mg2">{{cite web |title= Steinhoff shareholders approve Conforama deal |url=https://mg.co.za/article/2011-03-14-steinhoff-shareholders-approve-conforama-deal |website=mg.co.za |publisher=Mail&Gardian | date = 14 March 2011 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> a deal that boosted revenues and growth.<ref name="reut1">{{cite news|last1=Reuters|title=Steinhoff profit surges on Conforama buy |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/Steinhoff-profit-surges-on-Conforama-buy-20120306 |accessdate= 27 December 2017 |agency= fin24|date=2012-03-06}}</ref> 2014 through 2017 saw acquisitions in South Africa, the United Kingdom and United States,<ref name= "bloom">{{cite web |last1=Bloomberg |title=Steinhoff rejects allegations of dishonesty in accounting |url= https://www.fin24.com/Economy/South-Africa/steinhoff-rejects-allegations-of-dishonesty-in-accounting-20170825 |website= fin24.com | date = 27 August 2017 |publisher=City Press |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> which included [[Mattress Firm]] for $2.4bn,<ref name="rl1">{{cite news |last1=Laing |first1=Robert |title=Steinhoff’s US business secures $225m loan despite parent’s woes |url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/retail-and-consumer/2017-12-27-steinhoffs-us-business-secures-225m-loan-despite-parents-woes/|accessdate=27 December 2017|work=Companies / Retail |agency=BusinessDay |publisher= businesslive.co.za |date= 27 December 2017}}</ref> and [[Poundland]] for £597m in depressed retail conditions.<ref name="aayj1">{{cite news |last1=Armstrong |first1=Ashley |last2=Yeomans |first2=Jon|title=Poundland bought by South African group Steinhoff for £597m |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/07/13/steinhoff-picks-up-poundland-for-597m/ |accessdate=27 December 2017 |work=Business|agency=The Telegraph|date=13 July 2016}}</ref> Despite being partially funded with Steinhoff shares, the very large premium paid for Mattress Firm prompted scrutiny by independent analysts.<ref name="vdm"/> The financial press initially ascribed the growth in Jooste's empire to either good luck or fortuitous timing, but the dissenting voices grew silent as Steinhoff raked in 36% growth in its 2014/2015 reporting year.<ref name="mg1"/>
In March 2015 Steinhoff bought [[Pepkor]] from Wiese and his Brait holding company at R63 billion (then €4.8 billion), implying a very high [[price–earnings ratio|p-e ratio]] of 37. After a failed merger with [[Shoprite (South Africa)|Shoprite]] in December 2016, Jooste and Wiese raised new capital in 2017 to split off Pepkor's South African division, a move received with some skepticism, as it was seen as a way to pay off Steinhoff’s South African debt.<ref name="thom">{{cite news |last1=Thomas |first1= Stafford |title=Steinhoff: a giant raises its head |url= https://www.businesslive.co.za/fm/money-and-investing/2017-05-25-steinhoff-a-giant-raises-its-head/ |accessdate= 15 June 2018 |agency=BusinessDay |date=25 May 2017}}</ref> The Pepkor acquisition also occurred without a cautionary announcement, raising suspicions at the [[Financial Services Board (South Africa)|FSB]] about possible [[insider trading]] leading up to the deal.<ref name="insider2">{{cite web |title=Steinhoff, Brait share movements probed for insider trading |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Financial-Services/Steinhoff-Brait-share-movements-probed-for-insider-trading-20150625 |website=fin24.com |date = 25 June 2015| accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref> The split implied a 71% holding in new entity, Star, which managed more than 5,000 South African stores, more than any other retailer.<ref name="lerc">{{cite news |last1= Lerche |first1=David |title=Star: the curse of an embarrassing parent |url= https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/star-the-curse-of-an-embarrassing-parent/ |accessdate= 15 June 2018 |agency=Moneyweb |date=15 June 2018}}</ref>
On 4 December 2015 Steinhoff announced that [[Oldenburg]] authorities had carried out a 26 November raid on its European headquarters in [[Westerstede]], Germany,<ref name="raid">{{cite news |title=Germany raids Steinhoff offices ahead of listing |url=https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/germany-raids-steinhoff-offices-ahead-of-listing-20151204 |accessdate=8 August 2018 |publisher=fin24.com |date=4 December 2015}}</ref> in order to review its balance sheet treatment of transfers to subsidiaries or third parties. Three days later, on 7 December, Steinhoff International Holdings transferred its primary listing from [[JSE Limited|Johannesburg]] to [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange|Frankfurt]], as, in Jooste's words, the majority of the firm’s stores, customers and revenues were in Europe.<ref name="jc">{{cite web|last1= Cronje |first1=Jan |title=A Steinhoff guide for dummies | date = 8 December 2017 |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/a-steinhoff-guide-for-dummies-20171208 |website=fin24.com |accessdate= 20 December 2017}}</ref> Though describing it as "an important day in the history of Steinhoff", Jooste chose not to leave Cape Town to attend the event, citing "neck pain" which precluded travelling.<ref name="hb1">{{cite web |last1=Dörnfelder |first1=Andreas |last2=Köhler |first2=Peter |title= Börsengang ohne Chef |website=handelsblatt.com |publisher=Handelsblatt |url= https://www.handelsblatt.com/finanzen/maerkte/aktien/steinhoff-international-boersengang-ohne-chef/12688024.html |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref>
Steinhoff's share price peaked at R90 a share in 2016, making it the 15th largest company listed on the [[JSE Limited|Johannesburg]] exchange.<ref name="pc1">{{cite web |last1=Cairns |first1=Patrick |title=The funds most exposed to Steinhoff |url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/investing/the-funds-most-exposed-to-steinhoff/ |website=Moneyweb |publisher=moneyweb.co.za |date = 6 December 2017 | accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> The [[conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] employed over 130,000 people on five continents, and had become the second-largest home goods retailer in Europe after [[Ikea]]. In 2017, while its stock was held by some 340 investment funds in South Africa, in part due to its low volatility,<ref name=pc1/> its financial position began to worsen as its [[Operating margin|operating profit margin]] fell and [[net debt]] increased.<ref name="mm1">{{cite web |last1=Schwarzer |first1=Ursula |last2=Clausen |first2=Sven |title= Chef des Möbelherstellers Steinhoff im Visier der Justiz |url=http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/artikel/steinhoff-ermittlungen-gegen-markus-jooste-wegen-bilanzfaelschung-a-1164191.html |website=manager-magazin.de | date = 24 August 2017 |publisher=Manager Magazin|accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> Its March 2017 accounts showed €3.1 billion in cash reserves,<ref name="clpj1"/> and €18 billion ($21 billion) of exposure to creditors.<ref name="jb1"/>
Steinhoff limited its effective tax rate to between 8% and 12% for years, notwithstanding the company tax rate of 28% in South Africa, a fact pointed out as a red flag in the wake of the Steinhoff fallout.<ref name="vdm">{{cite web |last1=van der Merwe |first1=Marelise |title=Steinhoff may be 'the tip of the iceberg' |url=https://mg.co.za/article/2018-07-24-steinhoff-may-be-the-tip-of-the-iceberg | date = 24 Jul 2018 |website=mg.co.za |publisher=Mail&Guardian |accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref>
''[[Manager Magazin]]'' revealed in August 2017 that Jooste was one of the managers being investigated in Germany.<ref name="mm1"/> Prosecutors suspected that inflated revenues in the hundred million [[Euro]] range may have been reported on the balance sheets of subsidiaries.<ref name="bloom"/> On 4 December 2017 Steinhoff Holdings disclosed that it would release unaudited annual statements, and the next day Jooste resigned his position as CEO amid allegations of fraud and corruption.<ref name=iol-a>{{Cite news |url= https://www.iol.co.za/business-report/revealed-this-is-what-markus-jooste-said-to-staff-in-personal-letter-12298757 |title=REVEALED: This is what Markus Jooste said to staff in personal letter {{!}} IOL Business Report|access-date=December 5, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> Soon after he also resigned from Phumelela Gaming & Leisure, Kenilworth Racing,<ref name="sp1">{{cite web|title= Jooste – So Many Questions |url= https://www.sportingpost.co.za/2017/12/jooste-so-many-questions/ |website= sportingpost.co.za |publisher= sportingpost |date=16 December 2017 |accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref> and Mayfair Speculators.<ref name="le1">{{cite news |last1=Ensor |first1=Linda |title= High Court delays bid to liquidate assets of former Steinhoff boss |url= https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/business/2017-12-22-high-court-delays-bid-to-liquidate-assets-of-former-steinhoff-boss/ |accessdate=25 December 2017 |work=Business |agency=Sunday Times |publisher=timeslive.co.za |date=22 December 2017}}</ref>
=== Steinhoff scandal === ''[[Manager Magazin]]'' reported in August 2017 that Jooste was being investigated by German authorities.<ref name=iol-a/> In response Steinhoff's price slumped by 16% on the JSE, but recovered after the company denied the allegations.<ref name="bloom"/> This was followed by allegations of accounting impropriety made by Steinhoff's former POCO subsidiary.<ref name="ns1"/> [[Steve Booysen]] also alerted the board to possible accounting irregularities after engagements with Deloitte.<ref name="crot">{{cite news |last1=Crotty |first1=Ann |title=Tension at Steinhoff AGM as shareholders’ patience wears thin |url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/retail-and-consumer/2018-04-21-intense-steinhoff-agm-as-shareholders-patience-wears-thin/ |accessdate=14 June 2018 |agency=BusinessDay |date=21 April 2018}}</ref>
Jooste's December 2017 resignation as CEO of Steinhoff came as the company admitted to "accounting irregularities" within the group,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/steinhoff-ceo-markus-jooste-quits/ |title=Steinhoff shares plunge after CEO Markus Jooste quits|date=2017-12-06|work=Moneyweb|access-date=2017-12-14 |language=en-US}}</ref> and announced that it had approached [[PricewaterhouseCoopers|PwC]] to conduct an investigation into these.<ref name="groen">{{cite news |last1=Groenewald |first1=Yolandi |last2=Brand-Jonker |first2=Nellie |title= GEPF, trusts left bleeding as Steinhoff shares crash |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/gepf-trusts-left-bleeding-as-steinhoff-shares-crash-20171207 |accessdate=15 June 2018 |publisher=fin24.com |date=7 December 2017}}</ref> In a letter to staff on his resignation, Jooste apologized for "big mistakes" and that he had caused bad publicity for the company.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/steinhoffs-markus-jooste-admits-he-made-some-big-mistakes-20171206 |title=Steinhoff's Markus Jooste admits he made 'some big mistakes' |work= Fin24 |access-date= 2017-12-14}}</ref> Viceroy Research immediately tweeted a link to its 37-page report which detailed how Steinhoff had allegedly used off-balance-sheet entities to obfuscate losses and inflate earnings.<ref name="melin">{{cite web |last1=Melin |first1=Anders |last2=Farrell |first2=Greg |title= Viceroy short seller who flagged Steinhoff irregularities steps forward |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/viceroy-short-seller-who-flagged-steinhoff-irregularities-steps-forward-20180118 |website=fin24.com |publisher=Bloomberg |date = 18 January 2018 |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref>
Between 5 and 7 December Steinhoff's share price plunged from R46.25 to R10,<ref name="le1"/> and its bonds fell in line<ref name="jb1">{{cite news|last1=Bowker|first1=John|title=Steinhoff hires advisers as Investec cites credit exposure |url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/business/2017-12-11-steinhoff-hires-advisers-as-investec-cites-credit-exposure/ |accessdate=27 December 2017 |work=Business |agency=Sunday Times |publisher= timeslive.co.za |date=11 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="clpj1">{{cite web |last1= Casiraghi |first1=Luca |last2=Poh |first2=Jacqueline |title=What investors want to know from Steinhoff |url= https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/2017-12-22-what-investors-want-to-know-from-steinhoff/ |website=BusinessDay |publisher= businesslive.co.za |date = 22 December 2017 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> as [[Moody's Investors Service|Moody's]] [[Bond credit rating|downgraded]] Steinhoff bonds from investment grade (Baa3) to junk (B1).<ref name="bonds">{{cite news |title=Steinhoff woes mount as Moody's downgrades retailer by four notches |url=https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/steinhoff-woes-mount-as-moodys-downgrades-retailer-20171208 |accessdate=15 June 2018 |publisher=fin24.com |date=8 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="melin"/> Christo Wiese's Upington Investment Holdings held over 30% of Steinhoff's stock and was the biggest loser in the collapse.<ref name="thompson">{{cite web |last1=Thompson |first1=Warren |title=How Markus Jooste took Christo Wiese for over R200 million |url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/in-depth/investigations/how-markus-jooste-took-christo-wiese-for-over-r200-million/ |website=moneyweb.co.za |publisher=Moneyweb |date = 11 January 2018 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> South Africa's [[Public Investment Corporation|PIC]] (holding 7%<!--PIC claims 10%-->), [[Coronation Fund Managers|Coronation]] and [[BlackRock]] all made multi-billion rand losses.<ref name="groen"/><ref name="thompson"/><ref name="cronje4">{{cite news |last1=Cronje |first1=Jan |title= Parliament gearing up for Steinhoff probe |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/parliament-gearing-up-for-steinhoff-probe-20180111 |accessdate=13 June 2018 |publisher=fin24.com |date=11 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="brown">{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Justin |title=Steinhoff hits junk as R282bn in value is lost |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/steinhoff-hits-junk-as-r282bn-in-value-is-lost-20171210 |accessdate=14 June 2018 |agency=City Press |publisher=fin24.com |date=10 December 2017}}</ref> The [[European Central Bank]] sold its Steinhoff bonds after these had depreciated by 50%,<ref name="cronje5">{{cite news |last1=Cronje |first1=Jan |title= Steinhoff shares down 18% on news that ECB sold its bonds |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/steinhoff-chair-will-quit-supervisory-board-after-scandal-20171214 |accessdate=14 June 2018 |agency=fin24.com |date=9 January 2018}}</ref> while [[JPMorgan Chase|JPMorgan]], [[Bank of America]], [[Citigroup]] and [[Goldman Sachs]] all reported substantial loan losses.<ref name="melin"/><ref name="keller">{{cite news |last1=Keller |first1=Laura J. |title= Bank of America's $292m charge tied to Steinhoff turmoil |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Financial-Services/bank-of-americas-292m-charge-tied-to-steinhoff-turmoil-20180117 |accessdate=14 June 2018 |agency=fin24.com |publisher=Bloomberg |date=17 January 2018}}</ref> Lenders were owed over €9 billion ($10.6 billion),<ref name="bono">{{cite news |last1=Bonorchis |first1=Renee |last2=Mkokeli |first2=Sam |last3=Prinsloo |first3=Loni |title=Steinhoff bought forests linked to executives at inflated prices |url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/business/2018-07-10-steinhoff-bought-forests-linked-to-executives-at-inflated-prices/ |accessdate=8 August 2018 |work=TimesLive |agency=Sunday Times |date=10 July 2018}}</ref> but in June 2018 the majority were persuaded to a debt standstill<ref name="motso">{{cite web |last1=Motsoeneng |first1=Tiisetso |title=More creditors give Steinhoff breathing space |url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/more-creditors-give-south-africas-steinhoff-breathing-space/ |date =12 June 2018 |website=Moneyweb |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref> and insolvency was avoided.
It was soon labeled as the biggest corporate scandal in South African history<ref>{{Cite news | first = Aldi | last= Schoeman | date = 10 December 2017 |url=https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/high-life-big-fall-20171209 |title=Markus Jooste: High life, big fall |work=Fin24 | agency = City Press |access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> and the biggest corporate crash in the country's history.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2017-12-08-how-did-the-boytjie-lose-his-billions/ |title=How did the Boytjie lose his billions?|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-US}}</ref> As a result of Jooste's resignation, $11.4 billion was wiped off the value of the global furniture and clothing retailer.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-07/steinhoff-shares-extend-record-plunge-after-ceo-quits-amid-probe |title= Steinhoff Fights for Survival as South Africa Joins Probes |date=2017-12-07|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> This in turn had a ripple effect on several other companies, including its subsidiary Steinhoff Africa Retail (Star), which may have guaranteed some of Steinhoff's debt.<ref name="pc2">{{cite web|last1=Cairns |first1= Patrick |title=Steinhoff has cost investors almost R300 billion |url= https://www.moneyweb.co.za/investing/steinhoff-has-cost-investors-almost-r300-billion/ |website=Moneyweb |date = 13 December 2017 |publisher=moneyweb.co.za |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> In seven days of trading, the [[JSE Limited|Johannesburg]] exchange was hit by losses totaling about R295 billion ($24 billion), equivalent to 8% of South Africa's GDP.<ref name="pc2"/>
Steinhoff's share price dipped to R4.50 (down from R51.40 on 1 December) when the company's accumulated debt of R161 billion ($12.8 billion) was revealed.<ref name="st1">{{cite web |last1=Nombembe |first1=Philani|last2=Jordan|first2=Bobby|title=Steinhoff probe out to corral Mark Jooste's bolted horse |url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/news/2017-12-22-steinhoff-probe-out-to-corral-mark-joostes-bolted-horse/ | date = 23 December 2017 |website=timeslive.co.za |publisher= Sunday Times |accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref> By late December, Steinhoff shares were on the brink of collapse, as management could not ascertain the magnitude of accounting irregularities, or provide assurances concerning individual companies' cash flows.<ref name="tpv1">{{cite news |last1=Tshandu |first1=Palesa V. |title=Steinhoff shares strike near all-time low |url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/business/2017-12-22-steinhoff-shares-strike-near-all-time-low/ |accessdate=25 December 2017 |work=Business|agency=Sunday Times |publisher=timeslive.co.za |date=23 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="bloom1">{{cite news|title=Steinhoff Flirts With Collapse as Stock Rout Worsens: Chart|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-20/steinhoff-flirts-with-collapse-as-stock-rout-worsens-chart |accessdate=25 December 2017 |agency=Bloomberg |publisher= bloomberg.com |date=20 December 2017}}</ref> Steinhoff however won approval to roll over €690m of its financing,<ref name="clpj1"/> and its US subsidiary [[Mattress Firm]] secured a loan of $225m from [[Barclays]].<ref name="rl1"/> Steinhoff also sold PSG shares worth R4.7 billion to increase liquidity.<ref name="gt1">{{cite news |last1=Talevi |first1=Giuletta |title=Steinhoff unable to give details of irregularities |url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/retail-and-consumer/2017-12-19-steinhoffs-lenders-start-cutting-off-support/ |accessdate=27 December 2017 |work=Companies / Retail |agency=BusinessDay |publisher=businesslive.co.za |date=19 December 2017}}</ref>
In the wake of the scandal media articles identified Jooste's supposed mistress<ref name =news24a>{{Cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/exclusive-markus-jooste-the-blonde-polo-player-and-a-room-with-a-view-20171213 |title= EXCLUSIVE: Markus Jooste, the blonde polo player and a room with a view |work=News24 |access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> who occupied a luxury apartment in [[Bantry Bay, Cape Town|Bantry Bay]].<ref name="pvz">{{cite news |last1=Van Zyl |first1=Pieter |title=Chasing Markus Jooste's shadow in Hermanus |url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/chasing-marcus-joostes-shadow-in-hermanus-20180108 |accessdate=13 June 2018 |agency=News24 |date=8 January 2018}}</ref> Reports also revealed that his hard-nosed executive style earned him a nickname, "the seagull", as he would "fly in and shit all over his subordinates before flying out."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/christopher-rutledge/the-seagulls-name-was-markus-how-a-patriarchal-culture-at-steinhoff-allowed-it-to-hide-the-losses_a_23303325/|title=The Seagull's Name Was Markus Jooste: Steinhoff And The 'Stellenbosch Mafia' |date=2017-12-12 |work=Huffington Post South Africa|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-ZA}}</ref>
===Investigations and litigation=== [[PricewaterhouseCoopers|PwC]] was tasked with an investigation into possible accounting irregularities or non-compliance with laws and regulations, and resumption of audited statements were subject to its outcome. German prosecutors confirmed in December 2017 that they were still investigating four current and former managers of a group (identified in the German press as Steinhoff), for accounting fraud.<ref name="cronje6">{{cite news |last1=Cronje |first1=Jan |title= German prosecutors still probing Steinhoff for possible accounts fraud |url= https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Retail/german-prosecutors-still-probing-steinhoff-for-possible-accounts-fraud-20171207 |accessdate=15 June 2018 |publisher=fin24.com |date=7 December 2017}}</ref> Steinhoff announced in February 2018 that they had submitted a report on Jooste to the [[Hawks (South Africa)|Hawks]] on suspicion of fraud, for investigation and potential prosecution.<ref name="cronje2"/>
Christo Wiese’s Titan Group instituted a claim of R59 billion ($4.8 billion) against the Steinhoff conglomerate to recover cash investments made in 2015 and 2016. The prospects of this claim are however complicated by the fact that Wiese had been Steinhoff director since 2013.<ref name="Ziady">{{cite news |last1=Ziady |first1=Hanna |last2=Xolisa |first2=Phillip |title=Christo Wiese to sue Steinhoff for R59bn — but Dutch law may not allow it |url= https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/2018-04-26-breaking-christo-wiese-to-sue-steinhoff-for-r59bn/ |accessdate=13 June 2018 |agency=BusinessDay |date=26 April 2018}}</ref> Wiese had a 22% shareholding in Steinhoff, the European component of which appears to have been subject to margin loans with different banks.<ref name="steyn">{{cite news |last1=Steyn |first1=Lisa |title=Focus shifts to Steinhoff's ex-chair Christo Wiese |url=https://mg.co.za/article/2018-01-26-00-focus-shifts-to-steinhoffs-ex-chair-christo-wiese |accessdate=8 August 2018 |agency=Mail&Guardian |publisher=mg.co.za |date=26 Jan 2018}}</ref>
In December 2017 [[Barclays Africa Group|Absa Bank]] and [[Investec|Investec Plc]] applied for the liquidation of Mayfair Speculators, when Mayfair's Steinhoff shares failed to provide sufficient collateral for its overdraft facilities.<ref name="rvn"/><ref name="le1"/> Absa, who was owed R350 million, expressed suspicion about R1.5 billion of assets that were transferred as a [[dividend]] in specie to Mayfair's holding company in August 2017.<ref name="thompson"/> According to court documents, Mayfair owed Sanlam capital markets, Investec Plc and Absa more than R1.2 billion ($94 million) in total.<ref name="rb1">{{cite web |last1=Bonorchis |first1=Renee |title= Markus Jooste’s troubles deepen – Lenders sue over racehorse company non-payment |url= https://www.biznews.com/briefs/2017/12/21/jooste-racehorse-company-lenders-sue/ |website=BizNews |publisher=biznews.com | date = 21 December 2017 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> Mayfair disclosed liabilities of R1 billion and assets worth R350 million.<ref name="rvn"/> The [[Western Cape High Court]] postponed the banks' application,<ref name="le1"/> and the lenders subsequently agreed to grant Mayfair extension until the end of 2018 to facilitate a favourable disposal of its real estate and racehorses.<ref name="prins">{{cite news |last1=Prinsloo |first1=Loni |last2=Bowker |first2=John |title= Steinhoff’s Markus Jooste thrown a lifeline by banks |url= https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/retail-and-consumer/2018-04-25-steinhoffs-markus-jooste-thrown-a-lifeline-by-banks/ |accessdate=13 June 2018 |agency=BusinessDay |date=25 April 2018}}</ref>
In June 2018, a Dutch shareholders association, [[:nl:Vereniging van Effectenbezitters|VEB]], filed for damages against [[Deloitte]] in [[Rotterdam]], for their failure in vetting the accounts of retailer Steinhoff Int. NV. The association planned to hold the directors, company, accountants, and potentially the banks that promoted Steinhoff's listing, jointly responsible.<ref name="ster">{{cite web |last1=Sterling |first1=Toby |title=Steinhoff’s Dutch shareholders file lawsuit against Deloitte |url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/steinhoffs-dutch-shareholders-file-lawsuit-against-deloitte/ |website=moneyweb.co.za |publisher=Moneyweb |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
The German raid of 2015 recovered documents supposedly signed by Andreas Seifert, co-managing director of furniture chain XXXLutz. Seifert denied ever having seen or signed the papers, and filed criminal charges for document forgery.<ref name="mm1"/> After filing additional lawsuits against Steinhoff in three countries, Seifert managed in April 2018 formalize his controlling stake in POCO, which Steinhoff disputed.<ref name="matus">{{cite news |last1=Matussek |first1=Karin |last2=Simon |first2=Zoltan |title=Seifert, ending a bitter dispute |url= https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/retail-and-consumer/2018-04-26-steinhoff-sells-half-of-poco-to-andreas-seifert-ending-a-bitter-dispute/ |accessdate=14 June 2018 |agency=BusinessDay |date=26 April 2018}}</ref>
==Horse trainer and breeder== [[File:Owner Markus Jooste.svg|thumb|right|150px|<center>Jooste's racing silks]] Jooste entered the horse racing industry in the 1990s with 250 horses, and became the second biggest horse-racing investor in Africa,<ref name="speck"/> or perhaps the world.<ref name="mg1">{{cite web |last1= Goss|first1=Mick |title=Who's Who In The Thoroughbred Zoo |url= http://www.summerhill.co.za/blog/2015/10/9/markus-jooste|website=Summerhill Stud |publisher= summerhill.co.za | date = 9 October 2015 |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref> Jooste and his son in law, Stefan Potgieter, manage their horse racing interests through Mayfair Speculators, a wholly owned subsidiary of Mayfair Holdings that was founded in 1987. In 2004 Jooste became a partner in Klawervlei Stud, together with Johan du Plessis, Danie van der Merwe and John Koster, and they chose the [[four-leaf clover]] as their emblem.<ref name="dt1">{{cite web |last1=Thiselton |first1=David |title= Klawervlei on a High |url=http://www.seantarryracing.co.za/info_det.asp?ID=146|website=Sean Tarry Racing Stables |publisher=seantarryracing.co.za |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref> In the next decade other prominent investors joined the enterprise.<ref name="mg1"/>
Jooste's first horse, the stallion National Emblem, was bought for R100,000 in 1993 and became a champion.<ref name="ns1"/> Mayfair Speculators owned South Africa’s best racehorse, Legal Eagle, a six-time Grade 1 winner, and Edict Of Nantes, a dual Grade 1 winner. They were sold in December 2017 for R3.2 million and R9.9 million respectively.<ref name="speck">{{cite web |last1= Speckman |first1=Asha |title=Markus Jooste flogs his prize horses | date = 17 December 2017 |url= https://www.pressreader.com/south-africa/sunday-times/20171217/283210148589185 |website=Final Furlong |publisher=Sunday Times |accessdate= 21 December 2017}}</ref> In 2016, The Conglomerate won the [[Durban July Handicap|Durban July]] as an outsider.<ref name="vcdj1">{{cite web|title=“Striker” gives first July victory to Ramsden and the Joostes |url= https://vodacomdurbanjuly.co.za/2016/07/05/striker-gives-first-july-victory-to-ramsden-and-the-joostes/ |website=vodacomdurbanjuly.co.za |date = 5 July 2016 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref>
Jooste, in various partnerships, was a regular buyer at racing sales. In 2014 he impressed with his buying power at [[Arqana]]'s premium sale in [[Deauville]]. In 2015 he added 12 yearlings to his stables at [[Tattersalls]] Book One,<ref name="mg1"/> for a total of ₤4.3 million.<ref name="sp2">{{cite web|title=Jooste Spends Big At Tattersalls |url= https://www.sportingpost.co.za/2015/10/tattersalls-october-yearling-sale-2015-jooste-spends-big-at-tattersalls/ |website= sportingpost.co.za |publisher=sportingpost | date = 10 October 2015 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, Mayfair acquired 9 yearlings at the yearling sale in [[county Kildare]], Ireland for €2.3 million in total.<ref name="speck"/> In partnership with [[John Magnier|MV Magnier]], they bought a filly at Tattersalls for ₤1.68 million in October 2017.<ref name="sp3">{{cite web|title=Mayfair Speculators Hit Seven Figure Mark |url= https://www.sportingpost.co.za/2017/10/tattersalls-october-yearling-sale-book-1-mayfair-speculators-hit-seven-figure-mark/ |website= sportingpost | publisher= sportingpost.co.za |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> In 2017 he was named Equus SA's racehorse owner of the year for the 10th time in a row.<ref name="ts1">{{cite news |last1=Thomas |first1= Stafford |title=Jooste’s horses: shutting the stable door... |url= https://www.businesslive.co.za/fm/money-and-investing/2017-12-21-joostes-horses-shutting-the-stable-door-/ |accessdate=27 December 2017 |agency= financialmail |publisher=businesslive.co.za |date=21 December 2017}}</ref>
As of December 2017 Mayfair Speculators owned 350 horses in training, 100 mares for breeding,<ref name="speck"/> a considerable property portfolio, a 49% share in Klawervlei horse-breeding farm at [[Bonnievale, Western Cape|Bonnievale]],<ref name="rvn"/> and Steinhoff shares which were used as collateral.<ref name="rvn">{{cite web |last1=Van Niekerk |first1=Ryk |title=Absa applies for Jooste-linked company’s liquidation | date= 21 December 2017 |url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/absa-applies-for-jooste-linked-companys-liquidation/ |website=Moneyweb |accessdate= 21 December 2017}}</ref> Mayfair Speculators was also a shareholder in Cape Thoroughbred Sales (CTS), of which Jooste was a director.<ref name="rvn"/>
==Personal life== Jooste is married to Ingrid, and they have a son and two daughters.<ref name="Forbes" /><ref name="Racing Post">{{cite news |last1=Mathew |first1=Isabel |title=Big investor Jooste has grand plans for future|url=http://bloodstock.racingpost.com/news/bloodstock/big-investor-jooste-has-grand-plans-for-future/2029552/|accessdate=8 December 2017|work=Racing Post|date=7 February 2016}}</ref> He lives in [[Stellenbosch]].<ref name="biznews.com"/>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{short description|Term used to describe the running of a company where the communication channels between the managers and the employees do not work properly}} {{original research|date=February 2015}}
[[File:Mushroom management.png|thumb]]
'''Mushroom management'''{{course assignment | course = Education Program:University College London/MSIN1003 Information World (Autumn 2014) | term = 2014 Q3}}, also known as '''Pseudo-Analysis''' or '''Blind Development''', is a mocking term used to describe the running of a company where the [[Internal communications|communication]] channels between the [[management|managers]] and the [[employee]]s do not work properly.<ref name=oxfordref>{{cite web|title=Mushroom management|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100218343|website=Oxford Reference|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref> The term alludes to the stereotypical (and somewhat inaccurate) view of [[mushroom cultivation]]: "Kept in the dark and periodically given a load of manure".
==Description== Mushroom management is a style of [[management]] in which the personnel are not familiar with the ideas or the general state of the company, and are given work without knowing the purpose of this work, in contrast with [[open-book management]]. Mushroom management means that workers' curiosity and self-expression are not supported. The employees often have no idea what the company's overall situation is, because the leaders tend to make all the decisions on their own, without asking anyone else to give their opinion.<ref name="maranna">{{cite web|last1=Mar|first1=Anna|title=Mushroom Management|url=http://management.simplicable.com/management/new/mushroom-management|website=Simplicable- business guide|publisher=Simplicable|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref> This problem can occur when the manager does not understand the employees' work (in a programming company, for example) and therefore cannot communicate effectively with the employees.<ref name="CRS Press"/>
Mushroom management can also be found in environments that are unrelated to business. It can sometimes be found within schools, when students working in a group decide not to share information with the other students in the group. This means that they will appear more intelligent and hardworking during assessments.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mushroom Management|url=https://projectwiki.sis.uta.fi/wiki/Mushroom_Management|website=ProjectWIki|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref>
==Reasons== The main reasons for the development of mushroom management within a company can be found at the managerial level. Mushroom management often develops when managers see themselves as the sole decision-makers within the company, rather than the people who lead all the employees towards a shared success. This can often take place unintentionally: managers fear that their employees will discover important new ideas instead of them, which drives the managers to make bad decisions and prevent employees from taking an active role in their work. As a result, the employees end up doing this work in a mechanical, repeated fashion, without contributing in a more productive or active way.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mushroom Management|url=http://changingminds.org/disciplines/leadership/articles/mushroom_management.htm|website=Changing Minds|publisher=Changing Minds|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref>
==Benefits== The key feature of mushroom management is that the employees have limited responsibility over the company. The importance of the decisions they have to make is minimal, which can often reduce [[Occupational stress|workplace-related stress]].<ref name="CRS Press">{{cite book|last1=Neill|first1=Colin|last2=Laplante|first2=Phillip|title=Antipatterns: Identification,Refactoring and Management|date=2006|publisher=CRS Press|location=Boca Raton, Florida|pages=120-121|url=https://books.google.sk/books?id=6t3KzeaO7FIC&pg=PA122&lpg=PA122&dq=mushroom+management+book&source=bl&ots=aLAgIeqeCG&sig=cfQNC15pWOowgYksgduyxQMzdkY&hl=sk&sa=X&ei=WaRHVP-rD8bD7gbr_IDgBA&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=mushroom%20management%20book&f=false|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref>
==Consequences== The consequences of mushroom management can be extremely detrimental for everyone involved in the company. If the flow of information within a company is insufficient, the people involved often have a limited understanding of how to react in situations that require quick assessment and prompt [[decision making]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Gregory|title=Mushroom Management- Don't keep your workforce in the dark|url=http://www.managerwise.com/article.phtml?id=304|publisher=ManagerWise|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref> For example, a company that makes and sells shoes might research their customers' preferences and discover that these preferences have changed. However, if this piece of information is not passed on to the sales manager of an individual shop, then the shop will still display the "old" shoes and will not attract the customers' attention effectively. At the end of this process, the blame is sometimes even attributed to the shop assistants, because they are the employees in a direct contact with the customers.<ref name="CRS Press"/>
==Examples==
===Bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers=== [[File:Richard S. Fuld, Jr. at World Resources Institute forum.jpg|thumb||[[Richard Fuld]], [[Lehman Brothers]] CEO.]] During the [[bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers]] in 2008, considerable information about the bank's management was revealed, including the way [[Richard S. Fuld, Jr.]], the former CEO, organised the bank. The bank had started to concentrate more and more on excessively risky mortgages; however, neither the employees nor the public were aware of the bank's financial situation.<ref name="ibtimes.com">{{cite web|last1=Harress|first1=Christopher|last2=Caulderwood|first2=Kathleen|title=The Death Of Lehman Brothers: What Went Wrong, Who Paid The Price And Who Remained Unscathed Through The Eyes Of Former Vice-President|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/death-lehman-brothers-what-went-wrong-who-paid-price-who-remained-unscathed-through-eyes-former-vice|website=International Business Times|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> Fuld, together with other managers, had kept a significant amount of essential information secret, as well as lying to the investors and to all other involved parties. Everybody else had thought that Lehman Brothers were involved with a variety of investments, including both safe and risky investments; in reality, though, they had been working with a much more risky portfolio than was appropriate.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Montgomery|first1=Ashileigh|title=The Dearth of Ethics and the Death of Lehman Brothers|url=http://sevenpillarsinstitute.org/case-studies/the-dearth-of-ethics-and-the-death-of-lehman-brothers|website=Sevenpillars Institute|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> After the bank became bankrupt, Fuld refused to take the blame for any of these events, even though he was responsible for the concealment of the information.<ref name="ibtimes.com"/>
===Sinking of the ''Titanic''=== [[File:Stöwer Titanic.jpg|thumb|''Titanic'' sinking.]] Mushroom management can also occur during the handling of one-off, individual situations. When the ship ''[[Titanic]]'' hit an iceberg, only a few members of the crew were aware that the ship was going to sink. Most of the crewmen were not informed about the seriousness of the situation by the captain, which resulted in chaos and disorganisation. The captain attempted to act on his own, without incorporating the officers into his decisions.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smart|first1=John M.|title=Saving the Titanic- Crowdsourcing to Find Hard Solutions, and Unlearning to Implement Them|url=https://eversmarterworld.wordpress.com/tag/mushroom-management/|website=Ever Smart World|publisher=John M. Smart|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref>
==Countermeasures== Sharing information with co-workers and employees is often unavoidable; however, one of the most important tasks for a manager is to differentiate between information that can be shared with others and information that cannot be shared. A company should not share all its information with its employees, because that could be even more damaging. Managers should learn how to distribute information and how to communicate with the people they are responsible for.<ref name="maranna" /> The best way to avoid mushroom management is [[Transparency (behaviour)|transparency]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Monty|first1=Scott|title=Why transparency and authenticity wins in business and in marketing|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/feb/17/why-transparency-and-authenticity-wins-in-business-and-in-marketing|website=The Guardian|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
==Good mushroom management== Sometimes, mushroom management can be very helpful if it is handled carefully. This method involves the company's employees being divided into various groups, each of which has all the information which it specifically needs but nothing more, similar to a [[need to know]] approach taken in the military to control access to sensitive material. Meanwhile, the manager is in charge of giving each group the required information. This kind of management is extremely difficult, though, and requires considerable skill.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Munro|first1=Simon|title=I suck at mushroom management|url=http://consultingblogs.emc.com/simonmunro/archive/2008/10/20/i-suck-at-mushroom-management.aspx|website=EMC Consulting|publisher=EMC|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref>
==Accuracy of mushroom cultivation analogy== The term refers to the stereotypical view of [[mushroom cultivation]], where mushrooms are "kept in the dark and periodically given a load of manure".<ref name=oxfordref/> In fact, the most commonly cultivated mushroom, ''[[Agaricus bisporus]]'' is grown on a [[pasteurized]] [[compost]] substrate, not raw [[manure]] (common raw ingredients in [[mushroom compost]] are horse manure and straw). The chemical and microbiological nature of finished compost is, however, quite different from raw manure.{{fact|date=October 2018}}
Mushrooms are fungi rather than plants and therefore do not use photosynthesis. They can grow without light, but do not actually require darkness in order to grow.<ref>Beyer DM. 2003. [http://extension.psu.edu/publications/ul210/view ''Basic Procedures for'' Agaricus ''Mushroom Growing'']. Pennsylvania State University Cooperative Extension.</ref> Most mushroom cultivation is in fact done in dark locations (such as caves) for reasons of utility and to save on the expense of lighting, or, as with the case of the aforementioned ''Agaricus bisporus'', for appearance reasons. Light tends to give the mushrooms a brownish tint. Marketing research has shown the overwhelming customer preference for lighter specimens, so most of the producers try to limit light exposure. Some cultivated mushroom species, however, may need periodic exposure to light in order to induce fruition.{{fact|date=October 2018}}
